source: Canadian folklore . It includes songs , legends , jokes , rhymes , proverbs , weather lore , superstitions , and practices such as traditional food-making and craft-making . Folklore . These include oral traditions such as tales , proverbs and jokes .
summary:
Canadian folklore is a diverse and rich tradition that includes songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and practices such as traditional food-making and craft-making. Folklore is passed down through generations, often orally, and can be a valuable source of information about a culture's history and values.

Some of the most well-known Canadian folktales include the story of Paul Bunyan, the giant lumberjack, and the tale of the Wendigo, a cannibalistic monster. There are also many regional folktales, such as the story of the Headless Horseman of Ontario and the tale of the Bluenose ghost ship.

Canadian folklore is also rich in proverbs and sayings, such as "No man is an island" and "A penny saved is a penny earned." These proverbs reflect the values and beliefs of Canadians, and they are often used in everyday speech.

Weather lore is another important part of Canadian folklore. There are many sayings about the weather, such as "Red sky at night, sailor's delight" and "A robin in the spring is worth a king." These sayings are based on people's observations of the natural world, and they are often used to predict the weather.

Superstitions are also common in Canadian folklore. Some people believe that it is bad luck to walk under a ladder, while others believe that it is good luck to find a four-leaf clover. Superstitions are often based on fear or ignorance, but they can also be a way of coping with the unknown.

Traditional food-making and craft-making are also important parts of Canadian folklore. Many families have recipes for traditional dishes that have been passed down for generations. There are also many traditional crafts, such as quilting and rug hooking, that are still practiced today.

Canadian folklore is a rich and diverse tradition that reflects the country's history and culture. It is a valuable source of information about the past, and it continues to be an important part of Canadian life today.

source: Carlos Tevez has been told to terminate his contract with Juventus to complete a return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. The former Manchester City striker's deal with the Serie A champions does not expire until the end of next season but he has reportedly told the club he wishes to leave this summer. Boca have confirmed they are close to completing a deal for the 31-year-old, but club president Daniel Angelici has stressed that Tevez must terminate his contract with the Italians first. Carlos Tevez has shocked Juventus by suggesting he wants to leave the club this summer . Tevez is on course to win a second Serie A title with the Old Lady and still has a shot at European glory . 'We must be careful', Angelici told TYC Sports. 'We know that he wants to return to Argentina with Boca Juniors but he must first terminate his contract with Juventus, which runs until 2016. 'We are close to sealing his return and it will be done shortly.' The Argentina international joined Boca's youth academy in 1996 and went on to score 26 league goals in 76 appearances for the club before joining Corinthians in 2005. Although Juventus are reluctant to lose the league's top scorer - Tevez has netted 17 times this season - they have accepted the player wants to leave and have already started identifying potential replacements. Italian paper Tuttosport claims the 31-year-old has already decided to leave the club this summer . Tevez has always said he intends to finish his career back at his first club Boca Juniors in Argentina . Carlos Tevez                             17 . Mauro Icardi                              16 . Jeremy Menez                          16 . Tevez's international manager Tata Martino claims any potential move would have no bearing on the player's Argentina future. 'The most important thing for me is that Tevez continues to play as well as he is at the moment,' Martino told Italian paper Tuttosport. 'It doesn't matter whether that's at Juventus or Boca. Only he'll know what's best for his future. 'I will say this, though: Juventus are a great team, but so are Boca Juniors. It wouldn't be a step down.'
summary:
Carlos Tevez has been told to terminate his contract with Juventus to complete a return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. The former Manchester City striker's deal with the Serie A champions does not expire until the end of next season but he has reportedly told the club he wishes to leave this summer. Boca have confirmed they are close to completing a deal for the 31-year-old, but club president Daniel Angelici has stressed that Tevez must terminate his contract with the Italians first.

Tevez is on course to win a second Serie A title with the Old Lady and still has a shot at European glory, but he is said to be keen on a return to Argentina. He has always said he intends to finish his career back at his first club Boca Juniors.

Boca president Angelici said: "We must be careful. We know that he wants to return to Argentina with Boca Juniors but he must first terminate his contract with Juventus, which runs until 2016. We are close to sealing his return and it will be done shortly."

Tevez joined Boca's youth academy in 1996 and went on to score 26 league goals in 76 appearances for the club before joining Corinthians in 2005.

Although Juventus are reluctant to lose the league's top scorer - Tevez has netted 17 times this season - they have accepted the player wants to leave and have already started identifying potential replacements.

Italian paper Tuttosport claims the 31-year-old has already decided to leave the club this summer.

Tevez's international manager Tata Martino claims any potential move would have no bearing on the player's Argentina future.

"The most important thing for me is that Tevez continues to play as well as he is at the moment," Martino told Italian paper Tuttosport. "It doesn't matter whether that's at Juventus or Boca. Only he'll know what's best for his future.

"I will say this, though: Juventus are a great team, but so are Boca Juniors. It wouldn't be a step down."

source: Caroline Bouvier Kennedy ( born November 27 , 1957 ) is an American author , attorney , and diplomat who served as the United States Ambassador to Japan from 2013 to 2017 .
summary:
Caroline Bouvier Kennedy (born November 27, 1957) is an American author, attorney, and diplomat who served as the United States Ambassador to Japan from 2013 to 2017. She is the only child of President John F. Kennedy and Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy Onassis.

Kennedy was born in Washington, D.C., and raised in Georgetown. She attended the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Manhattan and George Washington University, where she graduated cum laude with a degree in political science in 1980. After graduating from college, Kennedy worked as a reporter for The Washington Star. She then attended Columbia Law School, where she graduated magna cum laude in 1988.

After law school, Kennedy worked as an associate at the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. In 1991, she joined the staff of the United States Department of Justice, where she served as an assistant to the attorney general for legislative affairs. In 1993, she was appointed by President Bill Clinton to serve as the United States Ambassador to the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women.

In 1995, Kennedy left the government to work as a freelance writer. She published her first book, Profiles in Courage for Our Time, in 2003. In 2009, she was appointed by President Barack Obama to serve as the United States Ambassador to Japan. She served in that position until 2017.

Kennedy is married to Edwin Schlossberg, an architect and designer. They have three children.

source: Cats and dogs have the advantage over marine pets in that they can interact with humans through the sense of touch. But that doesn’t prevent one man from dipping his hand in the fish tank and giving his blood parrot cichlid  a stroke. Capturing his remarkable relationship on camera, Roland Giroux gently cups the fish with his hand from within side the tank and then treats it to a massage. The fish begins relaxing in the man's hand and stays very still as the owner begins to stroke it with his finger . The fish initially moves away before swimming in a full circle and returning to rest in between the man’s fingers. The man then begins massaging the pet by running his finger along it and the fish stays completely still as if enjoying the sensation. Repeating the process, the fish swims off once more before immediately returning to the man’s hand to be stroked again. Later in the video the fish interacts further with the man by swimming up his arm and circling his fingers. The man places his hand into the tank and gently cups the blood parrot cichlid with his fingers . Before burying its face into his hand and remaining very still once more. The video concludes with the man removing his hand from the tank and the fish, clearly saddened by this, following it up to the surface of the water. According to Mr Giroux, who uploads many videos of his fish to his Youtube channel, the blood parrot cichlid used to share its tank with two other fish. The fish swims away from the man's hand a few times in the video but returns to be massaged . But he was forced to remove the other two from the tank when he noticed that they were bullying his prized pet. He then set about interacting with the fish by feeding it frozen blood worms by hand and eventually he noticed it becoming more sociable. After a while the fish enjoyed being stroked and Mr Giroux noted that it would become frustrated if he didn’t play with it on a daily basis. The fish begins swimming around the man's fingers and towards the surface as he removes his hand . The man massages and plays with his fish for at least 15 minutes each day. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of the midas and the redhead cichlid and was first bred in Taiwan around 1986.
summary: Roland Giroux has a pet blood parrot cichlid that he massages and plays with for at least 15 minutes each day. The fish used to share its tank with two other fish, but they were bullying it, so Giroux removed them. The fish now enjoys being stroked and will become frustrated if Giroux doesn't play with it on a daily basis. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of the midas and the redhead cichlid and was first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

source: Charles Manson . In 1971 he was found guilty of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people ( Abigail Ann Folger , Wojciech Frykowski , Steven Earl Parent , Sharon Tate Polanski , Jay Sebring , and Leno and Rosemary La Bianca ) -- most notably of the actress Sharon Tate -- all of which were carried out by members of the group at his instruction . Manson also received first-degree murder convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald `` Shorty '' Shea . After Manson was charged with the crimes of which he was later convicted , recordings of songs written and performed by him were released commercially .
summary:
Charles Manson was a cult leader who was convicted of orchestrating the murders of nine people in 1969, including actress Sharon Tate. He was sentenced to death, but his sentence was later commuted to life in prison. Manson died in 2017 at the age of 83.

Manson was born in Cincinnati, Ohio, in 1934. He had a troubled childhood, and was in and out of foster homes and juvenile detention centers. In the early 1960s, he moved to California, where he became involved in the counterculture movement. He formed a cult called the Manson Family, and attracted a group of young followers.

In 1969, Manson and his followers carried out a series of murders in Los Angeles. The victims included Tate, who was eight months pregnant, and four other people. The murders were carried out in a gruesome and ritualistic manner.

Manson was arrested and charged with the murders. He was convicted and sentenced to death. However, his sentence was later commuted to life in prison. Manson remained in prison until his death in 2017.

The Manson murders were a horrific event that shocked the nation. They remain a dark chapter in American history.

source: Charlie Austin's sixth-minute penalty appeared to have Saints in control, with Hull offering little in the way of an attacking threat. The hosts also lost starting strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to first-half injuries to compound the frustration of their fans, but the mood inside the KCOM Stadium was transformed in the space of two second-half minutes. First, Snodgrass - introduced from the bench for the stricken Keane - swept home his fourth league goal of the season from Sam Clucas' low cross before the Scotland international delivered an inviting free-kick that Michael Dawson headed past Fraser Forster. Southampton pushed for an equaliser but David Marshall made a string of saves in the Hull goal before Clucas produced a remarkable goalline clearance from a corner in the final minute of added time. The win - Hull's first in the league since 20 August - ends a six-game losing streak, although they remain inside the bottom three heading into the international break. Media playback is not supported on this device The best that could be said for the early loss of Hull's strikers was that it gave an opportunity for Snodgrass to return earlier than expected after missing the past two matches with an ankle injury. But his entrance from the bench following Keane's injury midway through the first half did not appear to be asking too much of the Tigers' top scorer - far from it. Instantly the hosts appeared to have greater urgency with the 29-year-old on the pitch, having looked sluggish and uninspired for 26 minutes before his introduction. The mood inside the stadium at kick-off was exactly what could be expected of a club bidding to avoid a seventh straight league defeat for the first time in 36 years. That run of defeats - during which 20 goals had been shipped - allied to widespread unhappiness among fans over the Allam family's running of the club meant the KCOM Stadium had a threadbare look at kick-off, with an official attendance of just 17,768. Empty seats dotted a ground that used to be filled to the rafters in the second and third tiers, and the dark mood of many home fans in attendance cannot have been lost on the players. Yet Snodgrass' tireless running lifted not only the fans but his team-mates, and his well-taken 61st-minute goal followed moments later by a perfect assist for Dawson was just reward for his endeavour. Southampton celebrated one of the most famous wins in their history by beating Inter Milan in the Europa League on Thursday, and a Hull side low on confidence did not look like dampening their mood in the opening exchanges. Austin's early penalty - an easy decision for referee Graham Scott after Curtis Davies' clumsy challenge on Maya Yoshida - had the visitors in cruise control, with Hull allowing them time and space to pass the ball around, albeit with little cutting edge. Virgil van Dijk's looping header off the bar early in the second half was as close as they came to doubling their lead, and that apparent lack of urgency came back to bite them when Hull struck their quick-fire double just after the hour mark. That was the spark for Claude Puel's men to push forward with greater urgency, but in former Cardiff goalkeeper Marshall they found someone in determined mood after a miserable start to life between the sticks in East Yorkshire. The Scotland international - whose elevation to number one ahead of Eldin Jakupovic coincided with Hull's slump in form - twice saved well from Austin as time ticked down, and also kept out a Yoshida effort. Dawson then came to the rescue to heroically block from Austin, before Clucas produced a stunning goalline clearance deep in added time, the winger hacking the ball off the line, against Jay Rodriguez and somehow over the bar. Hull City boss Mike Phelan, speaking to Match of the Day: "I'm really pleased for my players. We lost two players early in the game to what look like long injuries. The players are ecstatic. I thought we caused our own problems in the first half giving the penalty away and not getting the ball quick enough. "The players were a credit. Our keeper David Marshall has had a hard time of late but he was magnificent. Robert Snodgrass had the most unbelievable swollen ankle at one point which disappeared overnight. He showed great character. "Now that we have got three or four injuries, the international break has come at a good time for us. We will enjoy the next few days and start again." Media playback is not supported on this device Southampton manager Claude Puel, speaking to Match of the Day: "We lacked concentration. We lost the rhythm of the game. It is important for the future that we learn from this situation. "After a European game it is difficult to keep the same concentration. It is a good lesson for the future. "We know all the teams are difficult to play and to play every three days is difficult. We have to learn this and keep the same concentration every game." Following the international break, Hull return to action with a trip to bottom side Sunderland on Saturday, 19 November (15:00 GMT), while on the same day Southampton play host to leaders Liverpool, also at 15:00. summary:
Hull City beat Southampton 2-1 in the Premier League on Saturday, November 12, 2016. Charlie Austin scored for Southampton in the sixth minute, but Robert Snodgrass and Michael Dawson scored for Hull in the 61st and 63rd minutes, respectively. Southampton had a chance to equalize in the 89th minute, but David Marshall saved Charlie Austin's penalty.

Snodgrass was named Man of the Match for his performance. He scored one goal and assisted on the other. Dawson also had a strong game, scoring the winning goal and making several key defensive plays.

The win was Hull's first in the Premier League since August 20, 2016. It ended a six-game losing streak and moved them out of the relegation zone. Southampton, on the other hand, lost their second straight game and dropped to 12th place in the table.

The match was played at the KCOM Stadium in Hull, England. The attendance was 17,768.

source: Chelmsford Prison told residents there had recently been "numerous incidents" of packages being hurled over the wall.One former inmate said the jail was "notorious" for being "flooded" with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis.The Ministry of Justice said staff worked "extremely hard" to stop contraband from getting into prisons."However more must be done, which is why the Justice Secretary has asked us to look at how we can ensure prisons have the tools in place to tackle this kind of problem," the spokeswoman added.Follow updates on this story and other news from EssexA woman who lives near the prison, who did not want to be named, said she had witnessed packages being thrown over the wall "four times in two weeks.""It's getting quite bad at the minute. The prison wants us to come to an evening to talk about what to do if anything does get thrown over," she said."I don't feel frightened, but obviously it's not nice - I always lock the doors and everything."The former inmate claimed drones were used to fly contraband goods "straight up to prison windows", but the Ministry of Justice said there was no evidence of drones coming into the Chelmsford site.The spokeswoman said laws had been introduced which mean people who smuggle packages over prison walls could be jailed for up to two years.
summary: Chelmsford Prison has warned residents of "numerous incidents" of packages being thrown over the wall. A former inmate said the jail was "notorious" for being "flooded" with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice said staff worked "extremely hard" to stop contraband from getting into prisons, but more must be done. A woman who lives near the prison said she had witnessed packages being thrown over the wall "four times in two weeks." The former inmate claimed drones were used to fly contraband goods "straight up to prison windows," but the Ministry of Justice said there was no evidence of drones coming into the Chelmsford site.

source: Christa McAuliffe . She took a teaching position as a social studies teacher at Concord High School in New Hampshire in 1983 .
summary:
Christa McAuliffe was an American teacher and astronaut who was killed in the Space Shuttle Challenger disaster in 1986. She was the first civilian teacher to go into space.

McAuliffe was born in Boston, Massachusetts, in 1948. She graduated from Framingham State College in 1970 with a degree in education. She then taught social studies at Concord High School in New Hampshire.

In 1985, McAuliffe was selected by NASA to be a member of the Teacher in Space Project. She was one of six finalists who were chosen from a pool of over 11,000 applicants.

McAuliffe's mission, STS-51-L, was scheduled to launch on January 28, 1986. However, the launch was delayed several times due to bad weather. On January 28, 1986, the Challenger finally launched, but it exploded 73 seconds after liftoff. McAuliffe and the six other astronauts on board were killed.

McAuliffe's death was a national tragedy. She was a role model for many people, and her death was a reminder of the dangers of space travel. However, her legacy lives on. The Christa McAuliffe Planetarium in Concord, New Hampshire, is named after her. And the Christa McAuliffe Space Education Center in Framingham, Massachusetts, is dedicated to promoting space education.

source: Christopher Livingstone Eubanks ( born 8 August 1966 ) , known as Chris Eubank , is a British former professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998 . Christopher Livingstone `` Chris '' Eubank Jr. ( born 18 September 1989 ) is a British professional boxer . He has held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017 , having previously held the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 , and the British middleweight title in 2016 . As of May 2017 , Eubank Jr. is ranked as the world 's fifth best super middleweight by BoxRec , Also he is ranked as the seventh best middleweight by The Ring magazine and eighth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board .
summary:
Chris Eubank (born 8 August 1966) is a British former professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998. He is the father of Chris Eubank Jr. (born 18 September 1989), who is also a professional boxer. Eubank Sr. is a former WBO middleweight champion, and Eubank Jr. is the current IBO super-middleweight champion.

Eubank Sr. was born in Brighton, England, and began boxing at the age of 11. He turned professional in 1985, and won his first 15 fights by knockout. In 1990, he won the WBO middleweight title by defeating Michael Watson. He defended the title four times before losing it to James Toney in 1993.

Eubank Sr. retired from boxing in 1998 with a record of 41 wins (28 by knockout), 5 losses, and 1 draw. He has since become a boxing commentator and analyst.

Eubank Jr. was born in Hove, England, and began boxing at the age of 11. He turned professional in 2011, and won his first 15 fights by knockout. In 2015, he won the WBA interim middleweight title by defeating Billy Joe Saunders. He defended the title once before losing it to Gennady Golovkin in 2016.

Eubank Jr. won the IBO super-middleweight title in 2017 by defeating James DeGale. He has since defended the title twice.

Eubank Jr. is currently ranked as the world's fifth best super-middleweight by BoxRec. He is also ranked as the seventh best middleweight by The Ring magazine and eighth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.

source: Christopher Scott Kyle ( April 8 , 1974 − February 2 , 2013 ) was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper . On February 2 , 2013 , Kyle was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain , Texas .
summary: Chris Kyle was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper who served four tours of duty in Iraq. He was known for his accuracy and his ability to stay calm under pressure. Kyle was also a philanthropist who founded the Chris Kyle Frog Foundation, which provides support to families of fallen Navy SEALs. On February 2, 2013, Kyle was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas. Routh was later found guilty of murder and sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

summary:
**St Mirren striker Jordan Clarkson is set to make his debut for the club against Alloa Athletic on Saturday.**

The 30-year-old joined the Buddies on loan from Premiership side Motherwell in January and has been training with his new team-mates for the past few weeks.

Clarkson, who has scored 9 goals in 23 appearances for Well this season, is expected to be named in the starting line-up for the Championship clash at St Mirren Park.

The former Scotland international is relishing the opportunity to play for his new club and is confident that he can help them achieve their goals.

"I'm really looking forward to it," Clarkson told the St Mirren website. "I've been training hard and I'm feeling good. I'm just looking forward to getting out there and playing."

Clarkson is not the only new signing to be in line for a debut for St Mirren on Saturday. Midfielder Jamie McGrath, who joined the club from Livingston in January, is also expected to be in the starting line-up.

McGrath, who has scored 10 goals in 23 appearances for Livi this season, is a creative player who will add extra attacking threat to the Buddies' side.

St Mirren are currently eighth in the Championship, seven points clear of bottom side Alloa. A win on Saturday would move them up to sixth place.

The Buddies have been in good form in recent weeks, winning four of their last six games. They will be looking to continue that form against Alloa and move closer to the play-off places.

source: Colin Rand Kaepernick ( [ ` kæpərnɪk ] ; born November 3 , 1987 ) is an American football quarterback who is currently a free agent .
summary:
Colin Rand Kaepernick (born November 3, 1987) is an American football quarterback who is currently a free agent. He played college football at the University of Nevada, where he set several career passing records, and was drafted by the San Francisco 49ers in the second round of the 2011 NFL Draft. Kaepernick led the 49ers to victory in Super Bowl XLVII, becoming the first African-American quarterback to start a Super Bowl.

In 2016, Kaepernick began kneeling during the national anthem before games to protest police brutality and racial inequality. His actions sparked a national debate and led to him being blackballed by the NFL. Kaepernick has not played in the NFL since the 2016 season.

In 2017, Kaepernick filed a grievance against the NFL alleging that he was blackballed for his protests. The grievance was settled in 2019, with Kaepernick receiving an undisclosed amount of money.

Kaepernick is a controversial figure, but he is also a respected athlete and activist. He has been praised for his courage and his willingness to speak out against injustice.

source: Colombiana is a 2011 French action film co-written and produced by Luc Besson and directed by Olivier Megaton .
summary:
Colombiana is a 2011 French action film co-written and produced by Luc Besson and directed by Olivier Megaton. The film stars Zoe Saldana as Cataleya Restrepo, a young woman who witnesses her parents' murder at the hands of a drug lord and grows up to become a hitwoman. The film also stars Jordi Mollà, Lennie James, Amandla Stenberg, and Michael Vartan.

Cataleya is born in Bogota, Colombia, to a wealthy family. When she is nine years old, her parents are murdered by a drug lord named Don Emilio Restrepo. Cataleya witnesses the murder and is able to escape, but she is left traumatized. She is taken in by her uncle Emilio, who is also a drug lord. Emilio trains Cataleya to become a hitwoman, and she eventually becomes one of the most feared assassins in the world.

Cataleya is determined to avenge her parents' deaths, and she sets out to kill Don Emilio. She tracks him down to Miami, where he is living under the protection of the US government. Cataleya kills Don Emilio, but she is also captured by the police. She is eventually released, but she is now a wanted woman.

Cataleya goes into hiding, but she continues to kill drug lords and other criminals. She is eventually tracked down by the FBI, but she is able to escape. She then goes on a killing spree, targeting drug lords and other criminals around the world.

Cataleya is eventually captured by the FBI, but she is able to escape. She then goes into hiding, but she continues to kill drug lords and other criminals. She is eventually killed by the FBI, but her story continues to inspire others to fight against injustice.

Colombiana is a stylish and violent action film that is sure to please fans of the genre. The film is well-made and features strong performances from its cast. Saldana is particularly good as Cataleya, and she brings a lot of depth and emotion to the role. The film is also visually stunning, with some great action sequences. Overall, Colombiana is a well-made and entertaining action film that is sure to please fans of the genre.

The series follows Jim Lake Jr., a teenage boy who discovers a secret world of trolls beneath his town of Arcadia. He becomes the Trollhunter, a protector of the trolls from the evil Gumm-Gumms.

summary:
Conrad Dunn was a Canadian actor who began his screen career with the role of Francis "Psycho" Soyer in the 1981 film Stripes. He also appeared in several other films, including The Naked Gun (1988), The Naked Gun 2½: The Smell of Fear (1991), and The Naked Gun 33⅓: The Final Insult (1994). Dunn died in 2019 at the age of 62.

Stripes is a 1981 American comedy film directed by Ivan Reitman and starring Bill Murray, Harold Ramis, and John Candy. The film follows a group of misfits who join the United States Army in order to escape their mundane lives. Stripes was a critical and commercial success, grossing over $100 million at the box office.

Several actors in Stripes went on to have successful careers in film and television, including John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn, and Judge Reinhold. Larroquette is best known for his role as Dan Fielding on the NBC sitcom Night Court (1984-1992). Diehl has appeared in films such as The Silence of the Lambs (1991), Mulholland Falls (1996), and The Manchurian Candidate (2004). Dunn had a recurring role as Officer Carl Winslow on the ABC sitcom Family Matters (1989-1998). Reinhold has appeared in films such as Fast Times at Ridgemont High (1982), Beverly Hills Cop (1984), and Gremlins (1984).

"I think it's going to be amazing - I'm from Stratford so I love playing there [at the Copper Box]," said GB guard Teddy Okereafor. "This is the level we need to be playing at to make sure we're 100% ready for EuroBasket this year. "We've got a couple of guys who are going to be playing for the first time in London so it's going to be exciting for them - I think the atmosphere's going to be great." The game will be Britain's only home game before they compete at FIBA EuroBasket 2017, which starts at the beginning of September with a qualifying group in Istanbul, Turkey. After they play Greece, coach Joe Prunty's team travel to a four-team tournament in Poland, their last warm-up games before EuroBasket starts. source: Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after he chatted online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. Fears were raised over a planned murder bid involving police being ambushed after reports of a non-existent crime. Hughes admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court on Friday. He will be sentenced next week. Hughes said he was planning to make a false report to the police so that officers would come to the scene, prosecutors said while outlining the case earlier in the proceedings. He said he would then shoot them on the Dee Estuary. The threats were made on two occasions, late at night, while Hughes was drunk. Judge Niclas Parry, who was told the defendant had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009, remanded him in custody pending sentence. During a previous hearing, Hughes's legal team said he had not intended to kill himself and would not have carried out any threat to kill police officers. The court heard at the time, North Wales Police was particularly concerned because the defendant was on bail, awaiting trial for firearms offences, of which he was subsequently cleared. The Hope Line centre offers confidential support and counselling to people experiencing difficulty.
summary:

Hughes said he was planning to make a false report to the police so that officers would come to the scene, prosecutors said while outlining the case earlier in the proceedings. He said he would then shoot them on the Dee Estuary. The threats were made on two occasions, late at night, while Hughes was drunk.

Judge Niclas Parry, who was told the defendant had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009, remanded him in custody pending sentence. During a previous hearing, Hughes's legal team said he had not intended to kill himself and would not have carried out any threat to kill police officers. The court heard at the time, North Wales Police was particularly concerned because the defendant was on bail, awaiting trial for firearms offences, of which he was subsequently cleared. The Hope Line centre offers confidential support and counselling to people experiencing difficulty.

In summary, Craig Hughes was arrested after he threatened to kill police officers. He had previously been convicted of possessing a firearm. He will be sentenced next week.

source: Creedence Clearwater Revival , often informally abbreviated to Creedence or CCR , was an American rock band active in the late 1960s and early 1970s .
summary:
Creedence Clearwater Revival (CCR) was an American rock band active in the late 1960s and early 1970s. The band consisted of John Fogerty (guitar, vocals), Tom Fogerty (guitar), Stu Cook (bass), and Doug Clifford (drums). CCR is best known for their swamp rock sound, which combined elements of blues, country, and rock and roll. The band's most successful songs include "Proud Mary", "Bad Moon Rising", "Fortunate Son", and "Have You Ever Seen the Rain?". CCR disbanded in 1972, but their music remains popular today.

CCR was formed in 1967 in Berkeley, California. The band's original lineup consisted of John Fogerty, Tom Fogerty, Stu Cook, and Doug Clifford. The band's name was inspired by the Creedence Clearwater Revival album by blues musician John Lee Hooker.

CCR released their debut album, Creedence Clearwater Revival, in 1968. The album was a commercial success, reaching number 7 on the Billboard 200 chart. The album's singles, "Susie Q" and "I Put a Spell on You", were also successful.

CCR's second album, Bayou Country, was released in 1969. The album was even more successful than their debut, reaching number 1 on the Billboard 200 chart. The album's singles, "Proud Mary" and "Born on the Bayou", were both number 1 hits.

CCR released their third album, Green River, in 1969. The album was another commercial success, reaching number 1 on the Billboard 200 chart. The album's singles, "Bad Moon Rising" and "Lodi", were both number 2 hits.

CCR released their fourth album, Willy and the Poor Boys, in 1970. The album was another commercial success, reaching number 1 on the Billboard 200 chart. The album's singles, "Down on the Corner" and "Fortunate Son", were both number 2 hits.

CCR released their fifth album, Cosmo's Factory, in 1970. The album was another commercial success, reaching number 1 on the Billboard 200 chart. The album's singles, "Travelin' Band" and "Up Around the Bend", were both number 1 hits.

CCR released their sixth and final album, Mardi Gras, in 1972. The album was a commercial disappointment, reaching only number 12 on the Billboard 200 chart. The album's singles, "Sweet Hitch-Hiker" and "Someday Never Comes", were both minor hits.

CCR disbanded in 1972. The band's breakup was caused by a number of factors, including creative differences between the band members and John Fogerty's desire to pursue a solo career.

CCR's music has been praised by critics and fans alike. The band is considered one of the most influential rock bands of all time. CCR's music has been covered by a number of artists, including Bruce Springsteen, The Grateful Dead, and The Rolling Stones.

CCR's music is still popular today. The band's songs are often played on classic rock radio stations and at concerts. CCR's music has also been featured in a number of films and television shows.

CCR's music is a timeless classic that will continue to be enjoyed by fans for generations to come.

source: Cuadrilla, the firm behind the tests, said drilling had been suspended as a precaution after the 1.5 magnitude tremor - the second in two months. It will now examine the data collected by the British Geological Survey (BGS) before deciding whether to resume. A tremor centred on Poulton-le-Fylde on 1 April shared a "similar location and mechanism", the BSG said. Shale gas drilling, known as "fracking", involves shattering hard shale rocks underground to release gas using either hydraulic pressure or tiny explosions. Mark Miller, chief executive of Cuadrilla Resources, said: "We take our responsibilities very seriously and that is why we have stopped fracking operations to share information and consult with the relevant authorities and other experts. "We expect that this analysis and subsequent consultation will take a number of weeks to conclude and we will decide on appropriate actions after that." The process has proved controversial in the US with environmentalists alleging that shale gas leaking into their drinking supply could cause tap water to ignite. But earlier this month the Commons energy select committee called on ministers to support the process in the UK arguing that environmental problems associated with it in the US could be overcome by tight regulation and good industry practice. The BGS said it was also monitoring fracking as a precaution. There have been two small earthquakes in Lancashire since fracking began in the county in March, including the latest on Friday. In an analysis of the April quake published on its website the BGS said: "Any process that injects pressurised water into rocks at depth will cause the rock to fracture and possibly produce earthquakes. "It is well known that injection of water or other fluids during the oil extraction and geothermal engineering, such as Shale gas, processes can result in earthquake activity." The BGS said the April tremor took place 1.2 miles (2km) away from the drilling site but said its monitoring instruments were 50 miles (80km) away. Speaking about the latest quake, Dr Brian Baptie, head of seismology at the BGS, said: "The earthquake was felt by at least one person in Poulton-Le-Fylde. "Our analysis places the epicentre of the event to within 2km of the Preese Hall site. "Data from two temporary instruments close to the drill site, installed after the magnitude 2.3 earthquake on 1 April, indicate that the event occurred at a depth of approximately 2km (1.2 miles). "The recorded waveforms are very similar to those from the magnitude 2.3 event last month, which suggests that the two events share a similar location and mechanism."
summary:
Cuadrilla Resources has suspended fracking operations at its Preese Hall site in Lancashire after a 1.5 magnitude earthquake. The tremor, which was felt by at least one person, occurred on Friday 13 May 2022.

The BGS said the earthquake was "felt by at least one person in Poulton-Le-Fylde". "Our analysis places the epicentre of the event to within 2km of the Preese Hall site," Dr Brian Baptie, head of seismology at the BGS, said. "Data from two temporary instruments close to the drill site, installed after the magnitude 2.3 earthquake on 1 April, indicate that the event occurred at a depth of approximately 2km (1.2 miles)."

The BGS said the recorded waveforms are very similar to those from the magnitude 2.3 event last month, which suggests that the two events share a similar location and mechanism.

Cuadrilla said it was taking the "responsibilities very seriously" and that it had stopped fracking operations to share information and consult with the relevant authorities and other experts. "We expect that this analysis and subsequent consultation will take a number of weeks to conclude and we will decide on appropriate actions after that," Mark Miller, chief executive of Cuadrilla Resources, said.

Shale gas drilling, known as "fracking", involves shattering hard shale rocks underground to release gas using either hydraulic pressure or tiny explosions. The process has proved controversial in the US with environmentalists alleging that shale gas leaking into their drinking supply could cause tap water to ignite. But earlier this month the Commons energy select committee called on ministers to support the process in the UK arguing that environmental problems associated with it in the US could be overcome by tight regulation and good industry practice.

The BGS said it was also monitoring fracking as a precaution. There have been two small earthquakes in Lancashire since fracking began in the county in March, including the latest on Friday.

source: Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will take charge of Saturday's match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley's sacking. Swansea want to appoint their new boss as soon as possible, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement the first choice. "We've got to go with somebody who will to get us out of trouble," he said. "If we were to go down - and there's obviously that possibility - you look at the Championship and it seems to have got a lot stronger. It's not a foregone conclusion [to go straight back up]. "I know Norwich and Burnley have done it but it's difficult. Newcastle look like they'll do it but they're a big, powerful club who can hang on to a lot of their top players. I'm not sure we'd be able to do that. "If we go down, it's going to be tough to get back." Swansea were promoted to the Premier League in 2011 and quickly established a reputation as a well-run club with a team that played exciting, possession-based football. Their promotion capped a remarkable rise from the brink of bankruptcy a decade earlier and almost being relegated out of the Football League altogether in 2003. Curtis - a former player who was at the club throughout their rise up the divisions - believes the Swans have not been the same since Michael Laudrup left in 2014. "I think we have [lost our way]. It's just the change of management all the time," Curtis added. "The best eras were Roberto Martinez, Brendan Rodgers and Michael Laudrup. But we've probably lost a bit of the 'Swansea Way'. It has been diluted. "We've lost quite a few players too but have we adequately replaced them?" Media playback is not supported on this device Curtis believes the current Swansea squad is good enough to stay up, and the 62-year-old reminds every new signing of how far the club has come. "I know a lot of the foreign boys have seen [the documentary] Jack to a King. So they've got a brief history of where we were and where we are now," he said. "They might not be 100% passionate about it but they know where we came from and how important it is [to stay up]. Not just for the club but for the whole area."

source: Damon Albarn . Raised in Leytonstone , East London and around Colchester , Essex , Albarn attended the Stanway School , where he met Graham Coxon and eventually formed Blur , whose debut album Leisure was released in 1991 to mixed reviews . Drawing influences from alternative rock , trip hop , hip hop , electronica , dub , reggae and pop music , the band released their self-titled debut album in 2001 to worldwide success . His debut solo studio album Everyday Robots -- co-produced by XL Recordings CEO Richard Russell -- was released on 28 April 2014 and featured collaborations with Brian Eno , Natasha Khan and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir as well as sampling several rants by Lord Buckley .
summary:
Damon Albarn is a British musician, singer, songwriter, record producer, and multi-instrumentalist. He is best known as the lead vocalist and primary songwriter of the rock band Blur, which formed in 1989. Albarn has also released several solo albums, including Everyday Robots (2014) and The Nearer the Fountain, More Pure the Stream Flows (2022). He is also the co-founder of the band Gorillaz, the supergroup The Good, the Bad & the Queen, and the virtual band Africa Express.

Albarn was born in Leytonstone, East London, in 1968. He attended Stanway School in Colchester, Essex, where he met Graham Coxon, who would later become his bandmate in Blur. Albarn studied English and art at Goldsmiths, University of London, but left after two years to focus on his music career.

Blur released their debut album, Leisure, in 1991. The album was a commercial success, but it received mixed reviews from critics. Blur's second album, Modern Life Is Rubbish, was released in 1993. The album was a critical and commercial success, and it helped to establish Blur as one of the leading bands of the Britpop movement.

Blur's third album, Parklife, was released in 1994. The album was a massive commercial success, and it helped to make Blur one of the biggest bands in the world. Parklife was also a critical success, and it is considered to be one of the greatest albums of the 1990s.

Blur's fourth album, The Great Escape, was released in 1995. The album was a commercial success, but it received mixed reviews from critics. Blur's fifth album, 13, was released in 1999. The album was a critical and commercial success, and it helped to reestablish Blur as one of the leading bands of the Britpop movement.

Blur released their sixth and final album, Think Tank, in 2003. The album was a critical and commercial success, and it helped to end Blur's career on a high note.

Albarn has also released several solo albums. His debut solo album, Everyday Robots, was released in 2014. The album was a critical and commercial success, and it helped to establish Albarn as a successful solo artist. Albarn's second solo album, The Nearer the Fountain, More Pure the Stream Flows, was released in 2022. The album was a critical and commercial success, and it helped to further cement Albarn's status as one of the most important and influential musicians of his generation.

Albarn is also the co-founder of the band Gorillaz. Gorillaz is a virtual band that was formed in 1998 by Albarn and Jamie Hewlett. Gorillaz have released seven studio albums, all of which have been critical and commercial successes. Gorillaz are one of the most successful virtual bands of all time, and they have helped to popularize the use of virtual bands in popular music.

Albarn is also the co-founder of the supergroup The Good, the Bad & the Queen. The Good, the Bad & the Queen is a supergroup that was formed in 2007 by Albarn, Paul Simonon, Simon Tong, and Damon Albarn. The Good, the Bad & the Queen have released two studio albums, both of which have been critical and commercial successes.

source: Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were working at Harford Attachments in Spar Road when they were killed, shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday. The men are believed to have been working in a paint-spraying area. Their bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon. A forensic search has been carried out at the company, which makes buckets for diggers. Det Ch Insp Paul Durham said "significant progress" had been made with forensic inquiries and obtaining witness statements. "Evidence gathered so far suggests there has been a flashover explosion, which occurs when you have a build-up of toxic fumes," he said. "This, combined with some sort of ignition, has caused a fire-ball effect." The Health and Safety Executive said its inspectors and electrical safety experts would be gathering evidence.
summary: Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in a flashover explosion at Harford Attachments in Spar Road on Monday, February 27, 2023. The men were working in a paint-spraying area when the explosion occurred. Their bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon. A forensic search has been carried out at the company, which makes buckets for diggers. Det Ch Insp Paul Durham said "significant progress" had been made with forensic inquiries and obtaining witness statements. "Evidence gathered so far suggests there has been a flashover explosion, which occurs when you have a build-up of toxic fumes," he said. "This, combined with some sort of ignition, has caused a fire-ball effect." The Health and Safety Executive said its inspectors and electrical safety experts would be gathering evidence.

source: Danielle Cormack ( born 26 December 1970 ) is a stage and screen actress from New Zealand . summary:
The global economy is facing a number of risks, including a slowdown in China's growth, trade tensions between the United States and China, and Brexit. These risks could lead to a downgrade in the IMF's current forecast of 3.4% for global growth. The dismal picture has on-going ramifications for businesses and industries that bet on China's growth story.

David Lipton, second in command at the IMF, outlined some of these risks in a speech to the National Association for Business Economics in Washington on Tuesday. "The IMF's latest reading of the global economy shows once again a weakening baseline," he said. "We are clearly at a delicate juncture."

The comments come after weaker-than-expected trade figures from China showing that exports plunged by a quarter from a year ago. The IMF has already said it is likely it will downgrade its current forecast of 3.4% for global growth when it next releases its economic predictions in April.

The dismal picture is one that has on-going ramifications for businesses and industries that bet on China's growth story. For example, the global shipping industry is facing a slowdown in demand as Chinese companies import fewer goods. This is leading to job losses and bankruptcies in the shipping industry.

The global economy is also facing risks from trade tensions between the United States and China. The two countries have imposed tariffs on billions of dollars worth of each other's goods. This is leading to higher prices for consumers and businesses, and it is also disrupting global supply chains.

The global economy is also facing risks from Brexit. The United Kingdom is scheduled to leave the European Union on March 29, 2019. However, there is still uncertainty about what the terms of Brexit will be. This uncertainty is leading to business investment and consumer spending.

The global economy is facing a number of risks. These risks could lead to a downgrade in the IMF's current forecast of 3.4% for global growth. The dismal picture has on-going ramifications for businesses and industries that bet on China's growth story.

source: David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his decision ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. The BBC reported millions of pounds of public money loaned to Northampton Town FC appeared to have vanished. The MP has denied any wrongdoing. Mr Mackintosh was criticised over the loan to Northampton Town Football Club from the borough council - when he was leader - to rebuild Sixfields stadium and develop nearby land. About £10.25m of that money is now missing and the loan is subject to a police investigation into "alleged financial irregularities". The football stand remains half built. When contacted by the BBC last week, a majority of his party's local executive council said they would vote to deselect him. Mr Mackintosh had previously said he intended to stand for re-election. But in a statement, he said: "It has been a huge honour to be the member of Parliament since 2015, but I now feel it is the right time for my constituents to have a new representative."
summary:
David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, has announced he will not stand for re-election. The decision comes after a BBC report that millions of pounds of public money loaned to Northampton Town FC appeared to have vanished. The MP has denied any wrongdoing.

Mr Mackintosh was criticised over the loan to Northampton Town Football Club from the borough council - when he was leader - to rebuild Sixfields stadium and develop nearby land. About £10.25m of that money is now missing and the loan is subject to a police investigation into "alleged financial irregularities". The football stand remains half built.

When contacted by the BBC last week, a majority of his party's local executive council said they would vote to deselect him. Mr Mackintosh had previously said he intended to stand for re-election. But in a statement, he said: "It has been a huge honour to be the member of Parliament since 2015, but I now feel it is the right time for my constituents to have a new representative."

The BBC's political editor Laura Kuenssberg said Mr Mackintosh's decision was "a major blow to the Conservative Party". She said: "He was one of the party's rising stars, and his decision to stand down will raise questions about the future of the party in Northampton South."

The BBC's Northampton reporter, James Manning, said Mr Mackintosh's decision was "a huge shock". He said: "He was a very popular MP, and his decision to stand down will be a huge blow to the people of Northampton South."

Mr Mackintosh's decision to stand down comes at a time when the Conservative Party is facing a number of challenges. The party is currently in the midst of a leadership contest, and the Prime Minister, Theresa May, is facing calls to resign.

The BBC's political editor Laura Kuenssberg said Mr Mackintosh's decision was "a reminder of the problems the Conservative Party is facing". She said: "The party is in turmoil, and this is just another example of that."

source: David Mordechai Packouz ( [ pækhaʊs ] born February 16 , 1982 ) is an American former arms dealer , musician , inventor and entrepreneur . Packouz went on to invent a guitar pedal drum machine , the BeatBuddy , and is currently the CEO of music technology company Singular Sound .
summary:
David Packouz is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He is the co-founder of AEY Inc., an arms dealing company that sold weapons to the Afghan National Army. Packouz was convicted of conspiracy to violate the Arms Export Control Act and sentenced to seven months in prison. After his release from prison, Packouz founded Singular Sound, a music technology company that develops guitar pedal drum machines. He is the CEO of Singular Sound.

Packouz was born in Miami, Florida, on February 16, 1982. He is the son of a Jewish father and a Cuban mother. Packouz attended the University of Miami, where he studied music. After graduating from college, Packouz moved to Los Angeles to pursue a career in music.

In 2005, Packouz met Efraim Diveroli, a fellow musician who was also interested in arms dealing. Packouz and Diveroli founded AEY Inc., an arms dealing company that sold weapons to the Afghan National Army. AEY Inc. was one of the largest suppliers of weapons to the Afghan National Army.

In 2008, AEY Inc. was awarded a $298 million contract to supply weapons to the Afghan National Army. However, AEY Inc. was unable to fulfill the contract and was forced to return the money. AEY Inc. was also investigated by the Department of Justice for violating the Arms Export Control Act.

In 2011, Packouz and Diveroli were convicted of conspiracy to violate the Arms Export Control Act. Packouz was sentenced to seven months in prison. Diveroli was sentenced to four years in prison.

After his release from prison, Packouz founded Singular Sound, a music technology company that develops guitar pedal drum machines. Singular Sound's products are used by musicians such as John Mayer, Dave Grohl, and The Black Keys.

Packouz is the author of the book "Arms and the Dudes: A True Story of War, Love, and Betrayal." The book was published in 2015.

source: David Spade . He also starred and co-starred in the films Tommy Boy , Black Sheep , Joe Dirt , Joe Dirt 2 : Beautiful Loser , Grown Ups , and Grown Ups 2 , among others . Joe Dirt 2 : Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf .
summary:
David Spade is an American actor, comedian, writer, and television personality. He is best known for his roles in the films Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2.

Spade was born in Birmingham, Michigan, on July 22, 1964. He is the son of Judith (née Spadaro), a homemaker, and Wayne Spade, a salesman. Spade has one brother, Andy.

Spade attended Birmingham Groves High School, where he was a member of the school's drama club. After graduating from high school, Spade moved to Los Angeles to pursue a career in comedy.

Spade began his career as a writer for the sketch comedy show Saturday Night Live. He joined the cast of SNL in 1990 and remained with the show until 1996. During his time on SNL, Spade was known for his impressions of celebrities such as Cher, Kathie Lee Gifford, and Celine Dion.

After leaving SNL, Spade starred in a number of successful films, including Tommy Boy (1995), Black Sheep (1996), Joe Dirt (2001), and Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser (2015). He also starred in the comedies Grown Ups (2010) and Grown Ups 2 (2013).

Spade has also had a successful career in television. He starred in the sitcom Just Shoot Me! from 1997 to 2003. He also hosted the game show The Showbiz Show with David Spade from 2005 to 2007.

Spade is currently a co-host of the podcast The Showbiz Podcast with David Spade. He is also a regular contributor to the television show Lights Out with David Spade.

Spade is a single father. He has one daughter, Harper Spade, who was born in 2008.

source: Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to the men of the Arctic Convoys. Able seaman Charles Lewis, 91, from Calmore, Hampshire said he was "honoured and delighted". The Foreign Office initially did not allow Russia to honour the veterans as it broke the rules on foreign medals. The Russian embassy said the convoys allowed Russian soldiers to defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front. Mr Lewis said: "I certainly don't see myself as a hero - far from it - and I think all my friends and colleagues, many of whom sadly are no longer with us, would regard us as simply doing our bit for the war effort. "Although I have to say that Churchill's famous quote about the Arctic convoys' missions through the North Sea in winter as being 'the worst journey on earth' did strike a chord  - then and now." •They consisted of vessels which travelled from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union during World War II •Under constant threat of attack by German U-boats and aircraft, the craft also had to deal with severe cold, storms, and ice floes •By May 1945, the Arctic route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels. Thousands of Allied seamen lost their lives Source: National Maritime Museum Minister-Councillor Alexander Kramarenko from the Russian Embassy said: "It [the ceremony] is done for them because they have been expecting for a very long time to be recognized. "It is done for us as it was important for us. "The arctic convoy was a material expression of our wartime alliance and they provided weapons and ammunition that armed us to defeat the Germans on the Eastern front. "We and Britain were in it together." More than 3,000 men died during the maritime campaign that Winston Churchill was said to have called the "worst journey in the world". The Russian Embassy wrote to survivors in May 2012 that it intended to award them with the Medal of Ushakov as a symbol of the country's gratitude. But the move was blocked by the Foreign Office as its rules stated British soldiers could not receive a foreign medal if the act happened more than five years ago. The British Government created the Arctic Star in 2012 following a long campaign for the convoy veterans to be recognised. But campaigners believed veterans should still be able to receive the Russian accolade. The Foreign Office allowed an "exception to the rules" last year and President Vladimir Putin presented the first medals during his visit to London on 16 June 2013. The Ushakov medal is awarded to sailors who have displayed courage in the course of defending Russia or its interests.
summary:
The Arctic Convoys were a series of British and Allied merchant ships that sailed from Britain to northern Russia during World War II to resupply the Soviet Union. The convoys were constantly under threat from German U-boats and aircraft, and the harsh conditions of the Arctic Ocean made the journey even more perilous. By May 1945, the Arctic route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels, and thousands of Allied seamen had lost their lives.

In 2012, the Russian Embassy wrote to survivors of the Arctic Convoys that it intended to award them with the Medal of Ushakov, a Russian military decoration awarded to sailors who have displayed courage in the course of defending Russia or its interests. However, the Foreign Office initially blocked the move, as its rules stated that British soldiers could not receive a foreign medal if the act happened more than five years ago.

The British Government created the Arctic Star in 2012 following a long campaign for the convoy veterans to be recognised. However, campaigners believed veterans should still be able to receive the Russian accolade. The Foreign Office allowed an "exception to the rules" last year and President Vladimir Putin presented the first medals during his visit to London on 16 June 2013.

The Ushakov medal was presented to 26 British veterans of the Arctic Convoys at a ceremony in London on 25 February 2014. The ceremony was attended by Defence Attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko, Minister-Councillor Alexander Kramarenko from the Russian Embassy, and Able seaman Charles Lewis, 91, from Calmore, Hampshire, who was one of the veterans receiving the medal.

In his speech at the ceremony, Capt Kornienko said: "It [the ceremony] is done for them because they have been expecting for a very long time to be recognized. "It is done for us as it was important for us. "The arctic convoy was a material expression of our wartime alliance and they provided weapons and ammunition that armed us to defeat the Germans on the Eastern front. "We and Britain were in it together."

Able seaman Lewis said: "I certainly don't see myself as a hero - far from it - and I think all my friends and colleagues, many of whom sadly are no longer with us, would regard us as simply doing our bit for the war effort. "Although I have to say that Churchill's famous quote about the Arctic convoys' missions through the North Sea in winter as being 'the worst journey on earth' did strike a chord  - then and now."

source: Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad told the BBC "Syria is doing its best" to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons. Syria missed Wednesday's deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. Mr Mekdad said a shipment of weapons came under attack twice on its way from Damascus to the port of Latakia. "We shipped two shipments to the Syrian coast," he said. "The second shipment was intercepted by fire from terrorist groups." He added: "This is a serious business. Syria is in war, and the Americans and others have to take this into consideration." He described as "absolutely unacceptable" US Secretary of State John Kerry's recent condemnation of the government's use of barrel bombs in the city of Aleppo. The UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claims 246 people, including 73 children, have been killed in Aleppo in the last five days alone after barrels containing explosives and metal fragments were dropped by military helicopters. Activist group The Aleppo Media Centre claims 14 people were killed in barrel bomb attacks on the Masaken Hanano district on Thursday, citing footage appearing to show bombs being dropped from a helicopter onto a civilian area. "We are defending our people against terrorist attacks. We have never bombarded places with civilians," Mr Mekdad insisted, accusing the US of "still supporting terrorist elements" in the country. The Syrian government, via state media, also denied reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights said members of the Islamic Front coalition, dominated by the Ahrar al-Sham brigade and the al-Qaeda affiliate al-Nusra Front, mounted the assault, freeing hundreds of detainees. But state television insisted soldiers and security forces had "thwarted an attack against the prison by terrorist groups". The Observatory says fighting is still going on, but the Ahrar al-Sham brigade and the Aleppo Media Centre, a citizen-journalist outlet, say rebels now completely control the prison. It is reported to hold at least 3,000 detainees, including Islamists, activists and minors, in horrific conditions. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons. The US said last week that so far only about 4% of the stockpile - 30 tonnes - had left the country. US Defence Secretary Chuck Hagel said he was "concerned" that the UN-backed plan was falling behind schedule and said Damascus "had to take responsibility for fulfilling its commitment". Russia - a key ally of Syria - has said Damascus should complete the transfer of its chemical weapons to the coast for removal by ship by 1 March. A deadline was set last year for all the weapons to be destroyed by the end of June. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), which is overseeing the destruction operation, has admitted the process has been slowed down by security concerns. Mr Mekdad stressed: "Syria is committed to all its agreements, with the OPCW and the UN Security Council. We shall implement on time all our obligations."
summary:
Syria missed a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile of chemical weapons on Wednesday, 27 February 2014. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad said a shipment of weapons came under attack twice on its way from Damascus to the port of Latakia. He added that Syria is in war, and the Americans and others have to take this into consideration.

The UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claims 246 people, including 73 children, have been killed in Aleppo in the last five days alone after barrels containing explosives and metal fragments were dropped by military helicopters. Activist group The Aleppo Media Centre claims 14 people were killed in barrel bomb attacks on the Masaken Hanano district on Thursday, citing footage appearing to show bombs being dropped from a helicopter onto a civilian area.

Mr Mekdad insisted that Syria is defending its people against terrorist attacks. He accused the US of "still supporting terrorist elements" in the country.

The Syrian government, via state media, also denied reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights said members of the Islamic Front coalition, dominated by the Ahrar al-Sham brigade and the al-Qaeda affiliate al-Nusra Front, mounted the assault, freeing hundreds of detainees. But state television insisted soldiers and security forces had "thwarted an attack against the prison by terrorist groups".

The Observatory says fighting is still going on, but the Ahrar al-Sham brigade and the Aleppo Media Centre, a citizen-journalist outlet, say rebels now completely control the prison. It is reported to hold at least 3,000 detainees, including Islamists, activists and minors, in horrific conditions.

Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons. The US said last week that so far only about 4% of the stockpile - 30 tonnes - had left the country. US Defence Secretary Chuck Hagel said he was "concerned" that the UN-backed plan was falling behind schedule and said Damascus "had to take responsibility for fulfilling its commitment".

Russia - a key ally of Syria - has said Damascus should complete the transfer of its chemical weapons to the coast for removal by ship by 1 March. A deadline was set last year for all the weapons to be destroyed by the end of June. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), which is overseeing the destruction operation, has admitted the process has been slowed down by security concerns.

Mr Mekdad stressed: "Syria is committed to all its agreements, with the OPCW and the UN Security Council. We shall implement on time all our obligations."

summary:
Derek Hough is an American dancer, choreographer, singer, and actor. He is best known for his work on the television series Dancing with the Stars, where he has won six mirrorball trophies as a professional dancer. He has also starred in the films Make Your Move and Rock of Ages.

In 2013, Hough starred in Make Your Move, a Romeo and Juliet-inspired South Korean-American independent dance film. The film was directed by Duane Adler and co-starred Julianne Hough, Terry Crews, and Kim Soo-hyun. Make Your Move was a critical and commercial failure, grossing only $1.5 million worldwide.

Despite its poor reception, Make Your Move is notable for being one of the few Hollywood films to feature a predominantly Asian cast. The film was also praised for its dance sequences, which were choreographed by Derek Hough.

source: Despacito . On May 5 , 2017 , both an electronic version produced by American trio Major Lazer and Colombian DJ MOSKA and an urban version produced by Sky were released .
summary:
Despacito is a song by Puerto Rican singer Luis Fonsi and Puerto Rican rapper Daddy Yankee. It was released on January 12, 2017, as the lead single from Fonsi's fifth studio album, Vida (2018). The song was written by Fonsi, Daddy Yankee, Erika Ender, and Mauricio Rengifo and Andrés Torres. It is a Latin pop and reggaeton song with lyrics about a man who is trying to seduce a woman.

Despacito was a commercial success, reaching number one in over 40 countries, including the United States, where it became the longest-running number-one single of all time on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. It is also the most-streamed song of all time on Spotify and YouTube.

The song has been remixed several times, including a version with American singer Justin Bieber. The remix was released on April 17, 2017, and became even more successful than the original version, reaching number one in the United States and several other countries.

Despacito has been praised by critics for its catchy melody and danceable rhythm. It has also been credited with popularizing Latin music in the United States and around the world.

source: Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge . Released on 20 October 1995 , the film stars Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol . The film was shot in India , London and Switzerland , from September 1994 to August 1995 .
summary:
Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge (DDLJ) is a 1995 Indian Hindi-language romantic comedy film directed by Aditya Chopra in his directorial debut. It stars Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol, with Amrish Puri, Farida Jalal, Anupam Kher, and Mandira Bedi in supporting roles. The film tells the story of Raj and Simran, two young people who fall in love while on vacation in Europe. However, their families disapprove of their relationship, and they must overcome many obstacles in order to be together.

DDLJ was a major commercial success, becoming the highest-grossing Indian film of 1995 and the highest-grossing Indian film of all time until it was surpassed by Hum Aapke Hain Koun..! in 1997. It was also a critical success, winning several awards, including the Filmfare Award for Best Film. The film is considered to be one of the most popular and influential Bollywood films of all time.

The film was shot in India, London, and Switzerland from September 1994 to August 1995. The song "Tujhe Dekha Toh Yeh Jaana Sanam" was shot at the Eiffel Tower in Paris. The song "Le Jayenge Le Jayenge" was shot at the Matterhorn in Switzerland.

The film was released on 20 October 1995. It was a major commercial success, grossing over ₹1.3 billion (US$17 million) worldwide. It was also a critical success, winning several awards, including the Filmfare Award for Best Film.

The film is considered to be one of the most popular and influential Bollywood films of all time. It has been remade in several languages, including Telugu, Tamil, Kannada, Malayalam, and Bengali. It has also been adapted into a stage musical.

source: Do n't Say No is the debut extended play by South Korean singer Seohyun . Seo Ju-hyun ( born June 28 , 1991 ) , known professionally as Seohyun , is a South Korean singer and actress . She debuted as a member of girl group Girls ' Generation ( and later its subgroup TTS ) in August 2007 , who went on to be one of the best-selling artists in South Korea and one of South Korea 's most popular girl groups worldwide . Apart from her group 's activities , she has established herself as an actress , notably through her participation in the original and Korean versions of stage musicals including Moon Embracing the Sun , Gone with the Wind and Mamma Mia . She debuted as a solo artist with her debut mini album , Do n't Say No , on January 17 , 2017 , making her the third Girls ' Generation member to debut as a solo artist .
summary:
Don't Say No is the debut extended play by South Korean singer Seohyun. It was released on January 17, 2017, by SM Entertainment. The EP consists of six tracks, including the lead single "Don't Say No".

Seohyun is a South Korean singer and actress. She debuted as a member of girl group Girls' Generation in August 2007. She has also established herself as an actress, notably through her participation in the original and Korean versions of stage musicals including Moon Embracing the Sun, Gone with the Wind and Mamma Mia.

Don't Say No was a commercial success, debuting at number one on the Gaon Album Chart and selling over 100,000 copies in its first week. The EP also topped the charts in Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Singapore.

The lead single, "Don't Say No", was a moderate success, peaking at number 10 on the Gaon Digital Chart. The song was also a commercial success in Japan, where it reached number 10 on the Oricon Singles Chart.

Don't Say No was well-received by critics. The EP was praised for its mature and sophisticated sound. Seohyun's vocals were also praised, with many critics calling her one of the best vocalists in K-pop.

Don't Say No was a successful debut for Seohyun. The EP showed that she is a talented singer and actress with a bright future ahead of her.

source: Domenico Scala, who heads up Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian - as is Gianni Infantino, one of the five presidential candidates. Scala excused himself from the 2015 elections as he shared nationality with a candidate, Swiss Sepp Blatter. LFA boss Musa Bility says he will go to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. The battle to replace long-standing president Blatter takes place in 18 days' time. "Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations is clear that any member of the Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee who has a conflict of interest … is thereby barred from sitting as a member of the Committee and must be replaced," Bility wrote in a letter to Scala on Monday. Ahead of elections in May 2015 between Blatter and Prince Ali of Jordan - both Scala and Claudio Sulser, who was also on the Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, stepped aside for this reason. "Prior to the final review process, Domenico Scala (as a dual Swiss/Italian national) and Claudio Sulser (as a Swiss national) withdrew from their positions to avoid any appearance of a potential conflict of interest based on nationality," Fifa wrote at the time. However Andreas Bantel, a spokesman for Scala, says "the fact that a member of the ad-hoc electoral committee has the same nationality as a candidate does not result in a conflict of interest. "There is no such provision whatsoever in the relevant regulations of Fifa," he told BBC Sport. "For the last election period Mr Scala withdrew because the Swiss candidate was the incumbent President. Scala did so in order to avoid even any appearance of a potential conflicted of interest situation and simply as a precautionary measure on a voluntary base. "For this election there are five candidates with no incumbent President. Hence, there is no potential conflict of interest at all." It remains to be seen whether Bility will go ahead with his threat to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport. In his letter to Scala, he wants to know why the same process has not been followed ahead of the 26 February election. "Following an unprecedented period of sustained turmoil and damage for Fifa as an institution, the fairness and integrity of the current electoral process are absolutely vital for Fifa," Bility wrote. "If we do not receive confirmation from the Fifa Ah-Hoc Electoral Committee within three working days of receipt of this latter that you are stepping down … with immediate effect, the Liberian FA reserves its right to challenge that decision by all available routes." Bility had hoped to participate in the elections himself before being denied by the Electoral Committee in November after failing an eligibility check. On Saturday, the Liberian pledged his vote to Prince Ali while urging his fellow Africans to do the same. Alongside Prince Ali and Infantino, Frenchman Jerome Champagne, Bahrain's Sheikh Salman and South Africa's Tokyo Sexwale are also bidding to replace Blatter as president. The election, which is voted on by Fifa's 209 members, will take place in the organisation's headquarters in the Swiss city Zurich.
