source: Shooter (2007 film) . The film follows Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger ( Mark Wahlberg ) , who is framed for murder by a rogue secret private military company unit . Shooter (TV series) . The show stars Ryan Phillippe in the lead role of Bob Lee Swagger an expert marksman living in exile who is coaxed back into action after learning of a plot to kill the president .
summary:
Shooter is a 2007 American action thriller film directed by Antoine Fuqua and written by Jonathan Lemkin and Michael Brandt. The film stars Mark Wahlberg as Bob Lee Swagger, a former Marine Corps Scout Sniper who is framed for the assassination attempt on the President of the United States. The film also stars Michael Peña, Kate Mara, Ned Beatty, and Danny Glover.

The film was released in the United States on March 23, 2007. It received mixed reviews from critics, with praise for Wahlberg's performance and Fuqua's direction, but criticism for its screenplay. The film was a box office success, grossing over $295 million worldwide against its $60 million budget.

A television series adaptation of the film, also titled Shooter, premiered on USA Network on November 15, 2016. The series stars Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, and is produced by Paramount Television and Universal Cable Productions. The series was canceled after three seasons on August 16, 2018.

The film and the television series are both based on the 1993 novel of the same name by Stephen Hunter. The novel was the first in a series of novels featuring Bob Lee Swagger.

The film and the television series follow the same basic plot. Bob Lee Swagger is a former Marine Corps Scout Sniper who is framed for the assassination attempt on the President of the United States. Swagger must clear his name and stop the real assassins before they can strike again.

The film and the television series differ in some ways. The film is set in the present day, while the television series is set in the near future. The film also has a different ending than the television series.

Despite their differences, the film and the television series are both exciting and suspenseful thrillers. They are both worth watching for fans of action movies and thrillers.

source: Sick of awkward father-daughter portraits? Well one photographer has found an effective - if a little odd - way of making them more interesting. Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's latest series of images capture po-faced teenagers pictured next to their fathers leaping into the air. In each picture the daughter looks directly into the camera smiling while her father pulls a dramatic pose. A series of images by photographer Yûki Aoyama sees fathers leaping into the air next to their daughters . The images are from the 37-year-old's latest book which roughly translates into Daughter and Salary Man. According to the  photographer's website the images allow the father who usually has to act serious to express his fun side by being 'a hero jumping the sky, enfold(ing) strong excitement and hope.' Salary man may refer to the choice of clothing in the shoot which sees each dad in a sharply dressed suit. The images see the fathers pull energetic poses despite their age with some of the expressions of the older fathers looking slightly pained. Very little else is known about the pictures or why they have come into existence but they are already drumming up plenty of interest online for their curious nature. The 37-year-old's images are said to be part of a book which roughly translates as Daughter and Salaryman . Each image sees the daughter stood po-faced as their father makes an energetic leap . Some of the older fathers adopt a pained expression as they make their jump . Each photograph sees the daughter wearing casual clothing with her father in a sharp suit . The pictures see the families pose in front of various Japanese landmarks . Very little is known about the set of photos but they are already drumming up plenty of interest online . Some of the jumps are more subtle than others with this father opting for a classic jump . This young girl can't help but giggle at her dad's ambitious leap . This dapper dad adds a peace gesture into his final pose . This father can't help but jump for joy in his portrait .
summary:
Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has taken a series of images of fathers leaping into the air next to their daughters. The images are from Aoyama's latest book, which roughly translates into "Daughter and Salary Man." The photographer's website says that the images allow the father, who usually has to act serious, to express his fun side by being "a hero jumping the sky, enfold(ing) strong excitement and hope." The images have been met with mixed reactions online, with some people finding them humorous and others finding them strange.

Here are some of the key pieces of information from the passage:

* Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has taken a series of images of fathers leaping into the air next to their daughters.
* The images are from Aoyama's latest book, which roughly translates into "Daughter and Salary Man."
* The photographer's website says that the images allow the father, who usually has to act serious, to express his fun side by being "a hero jumping the sky, enfold(ing) strong excitement and hope."
* The images have been met with mixed reactions online, with some people finding them humorous and others finding them strange.

source: Sidse Babett Knudsen ( [ ˈsisə b̥ab̥ɛd̥ ˈkʰnusn̩ ] ; born 22 November 1968 ) is a Danish actress who works in theatre , television , and film .
summary:
Sidse Babett Knudsen (born 22 November 1968) is a Danish actress who works in theatre, television, and film. She is best known for her role as Birgitte Nyborg in the Danish political drama series Borgen (2010–2013), for which she won a BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Leading Role. She has also appeared in films such as The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009), A Royal Affair (2012), and The Imitation Game (2014).

Knudsen was born in Copenhagen, Denmark. She is the daughter of a Danish father and a French mother. She began her acting career in the early 1990s, appearing in a number of Danish television series and films. In 1998, she made her international debut in the film Mifune's Last Song.

Knudsen's breakthrough role came in 2010, when she was cast as Birgitte Nyborg in the Danish political drama series Borgen. The series was a critical and commercial success, and Knudsen's performance was widely praised. She won a BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Leading Role for her performance in the series.

Knudsen has continued to work in both Danish and international films and television series since Borgen. She has appeared in films such as The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009), A Royal Affair (2012), and The Imitation Game (2014). She has also appeared in television series such as Westworld (2016–2018) and The Crown (2016–present).

Knudsen is a highly respected actress with a successful career in both Denmark and internationally. She is known for her versatility and her ability to bring complex characters to life.

source: Sidwell, 34, has made 32 Championship appearances this season to help the Seagulls achieve promotion to the top flight for the first time in 34 years. With his contract due to expire at the end of the campaign, the midfielder is now hoping to sign a new deal. "I want to be a part of it next year because I know we can stay in the Premier League," he said. Brighton's recent win over Wigan confirmed their promotion, and with a four-point lead over second-placed Newcastle, Chris Hughton's side are now hoping to wrap up the league title in the final two matches. Sidwell made 19 appearances for Albion on loan from Stoke during 2015-16 before signing a one-year deal with Brighton in June 2016. He has previously played in the Premier League with Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham and Stoke and believes he deserves the opportunity to play at the top level again. Sidwell told BBC Radio Sussex: "When I signed the contract last year no-one expected me to play as many games as I have. I've probably given a better impact than expected. "When I have played I've played well, I've put my best foot forward and I've given myself every opportunity to earn a new deal. "If there's one on the table then hopefully we can thrash it out, it can be done and we can enjoy the summer."
summary: Sidwell, 34, has made 32 Championship appearances this season to help Brighton achieve promotion to the Premier League. His contract is due to expire at the end of the season, but he is hoping to sign a new deal. He believes he deserves the opportunity to play at the top level again.

source: Sikkim ( [ ˈsɪkᵻm ] ) is a northeastern state of India .
summary:
Sikkim is a northeastern state of India. It is bordered by Bhutan to the west, China to the north and east, Nepal to the south, and West Bengal to the southwest. The state has a population of 610,577 and an area of 7,096 square kilometers (2,740 sq mi). Gangtok is the capital of Sikkim.

Sikkim is a mountainous state with a high altitude. The highest point in Sikkim is Kanchenjunga, the third highest mountain in the world. The state has a temperate climate with four distinct seasons.

Sikkim is a popular tourist destination. The state is home to many natural attractions, including Mount Kanchenjunga, Nathula Pass, and Yumthang Valley. Sikkim is also home to a number of Buddhist monasteries, including Rumtek Monastery and Enchey Monastery.

Sikkim is a member of the North Eastern Council, a regional planning body for the northeastern states of India. The state is also a member of the BBIN, a sub-regional grouping of Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, and Nepal.

Sikkim is a beautiful and diverse state with a rich history and culture. The state is a popular tourist destination and is home to a number of natural and cultural attractions.

source: Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios ( [ siˈmon boˈliβar ] ; 24 July 1783 -- 17 December 1830 ) , known as El Libertador , was a Venezuelan military and political leader who played a leading role in the establishment of Venezuela , Bolivia , Colombia , Ecuador , Peru and Panama as sovereign states , independent of Spanish rule .
summary:
Simón Bolívar was a Venezuelan military and political leader who played a leading role in the establishment of Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as sovereign states, independent of Spanish rule. He is considered one of the most important figures in Latin American history.

Bolívar was born into a wealthy family in Caracas, Venezuela, on July 24, 1783. He studied law in Spain and returned to Venezuela in 1807. In 1810, he joined the Venezuelan independence movement and led the country to independence from Spain in 1811.

Bolívar then went on to lead the independence movements in Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Bolivia. He is credited with liberating much of South America from Spanish rule.

Bolívar was a controversial figure. He was autocratic and often used violence to achieve his goals. However, he is also considered a hero for his role in liberating South America from Spanish rule.

Bolívar died in Santa Marta, Colombia, on December 17, 1830. He was 47 years old.

source: Sir Bradley Wiggins will bid for cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, who is 35 on April 28, will attempt to add to his accomplishments by riding the furthest distance in 60 minutes at the Lee Valley VeloPark. 'The Hour Record is a holy grail for cyclists,' Wiggins said. Four-time Olympic champion Bradley Wiggins will bid to break cycling's hour record in June . Wiggins finished his Team Sky career in the Paris-Roubaix 253.5km one-day race on Sunday . Australian rider Rohan Dennis poses after breaking the world hour record on February 8 in Grenchen . 'It's been fought over tooth and nail by some of the greatest names in our sport for over a hundred years and it's time for me to have a crack at it. 'I like the idea of challenging myself and want to motivate people to do the same - so why not get your bike out of the shed and see how far you can go in an hour?' Wiggins, whose track pedigree includes three Olympic gold medals, is expected to set a mark which will last for some time. Wiggins will hope for a capacity 6,000 crowd to spur on his attempt, with tickets going on sale from April 19, while the event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. In June, Wiggins will hope to race in front of a sell-out crowd at London's Olympic Velodrome . Wiggins (left) alongside his Team Sky colleague Luke Rowe after the pair raced the Paris-Roubaix . Wiggins will look to beat the record of Dennis (pictured), who managed to cycle 52.491km in an hour . The Briton finished his Team Sky career at Paris-Roubaix last Sunday and will ride in next month's inaugural Tour de Yorkshire for his eponymous team before preparing for the Hour as part of his return to the track. The world time-trial champion is targeting a British record eighth Olympic medal - he has four gold, one silver and two bronze - at the 2016 Rio Olympics in the four-man, four-kilometre team pursuit. The current Hour record is 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February after the UCI, cycling's world governing body, reformed regulations, reigniting interest in the event. German Jens Voigt was the first to make an attempt last September, recording 51.115km, a mark which stood for six weeks before Austria's Matthias Brandle rode 51.852km, while Jack Bobridge was the first to fall short in his attempt. Dennis' mark will come under threat from Briton Alex Dowsett, who will make his attempt on May 2 in Manchester having had to postpone it previously after suffering a broken collarbone. Tickets to watch Sir Bradley Wiggins attempt to break the UCI Hour Record at the Lee Valley VeloPark on June 7 will go on sale to the general public through Sky Tickets from Friday, April 19 (10am) price £49, £39 and £29, on line sale only through the Sky Tickets website.
summary: Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break the UCI Hour Record on June 7 at the Lee Valley VeloPark in London. The current record is 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins is expected to set a mark which will last for some time. Tickets to watch the attempt go on sale on April 19.

source: Sir Donald George `` Don '' Bradman , AC ( 27 August 1908 -- 25 February 2001 ) , often referred to as `` The Don '' , was an Australian cricketer , widely acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all time . Bradman retained a pre-eminent position in the game by acting as an administrator , selector and writer for three decades following his retirement .
summary:
Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, AC (27 August 1908 – 25 February 2001), often referred to as "The Don", was an Australian cricketer widely acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all time. Bradman retained a pre-eminent position in the game by acting as an administrator, selector and writer for three decades following his retirement.

Bradman's Test batting average of 99.94 is the highest of all time, and he is the only player to have scored a triple century in Test cricket. He was a member of the Australian team that won the Ashes in 1930, 1932–33, 1934–35, 1936–37 and 1948. He was also a member of the Australian team that won the World Cup in 1956.

Bradman was born in Bowral, New South Wales, and made his Test debut for Australia in 1928 at the age of 19. He quickly established himself as one of the world's leading batsmen, and in 1930 he scored 334 runs in the second innings of the fifth Test against England at Headingley, which remains the highest individual score in Test cricket.

Bradman retired from Test cricket in 1948, after scoring 6,996 runs in 52 Tests at an average of 99.94. He was knighted in 1949, and was made a Companion of the Order of Australia in 1998.

Bradman died in 2001 at the age of 92. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest sportsmen of all time.

source: Sir Donald George `` Don '' Bradman , AC ( 27 August 1908 -- 25 February 2001 ) , often referred to as `` The Don '' , was an Australian cricketer , widely acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all time . Even after he became reclusive in his declining years his opinion was highly sought , and his status as a national icon was still recognised -- more than 50 years after his retirement as a Test player , in 2001 , Prime Minister John Howard of Australia called him the `` greatest living Australian '' .
summary:
Don Bradman was an Australian cricketer widely acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all time. He was born on August 27, 1908, and died on February 25, 2001. He was knighted in 1949 and made a Companion of the Order of Australia in 1979.

Bradman's batting average of 99.94 is the highest in Test cricket history. He scored 6,996 runs in 52 Tests, including 33 centuries. He was also a successful captain, leading Australia to victory in the Ashes in 1930, 1932-33, and 1936-37.

Bradman was a national icon in Australia. He was known for his dedication to cricket and his determination to win. He was also a popular figure in the media and was often interviewed and photographed.

Bradman's legacy is immense. He is considered one of the greatest athletes of all time and his records are unlikely to be broken. He is also a symbol of Australian pride and his name is synonymous with cricket.

source: Smith, 26, already leads the one-day side and will also captain the Twenty20 team in the absence of the injured Aaron Finch. Fellow batsman David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain. "At 26, Steve is a fine young man with extraordinary talent," said national selector Rod Marsh. "He is highly regarded by the selectors and we congratulate him on being appointed to the role on an ongoing basis. He should be incredibly proud." Clarke, 34, confirmed his decision to retire after his side surrendered the Ashes with a heavy defeat by England at Trent Bridge, which gave the hosts a 3-1 lead. Smith had already captained the side in three Tests against India last summer, when Clarke was recovering from hamstring surgery and back issues. The New South Welshman has played in 32 Tests for his country, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. Media playback is not supported on this device "When Michael made his decision to retire last week it was a very straightforward decision for us to nominate Steve as his successor," added Marsh. "He has big shoes to fill but everything about him suggests he is the right man for the job." Warner has earned the vice-captain's role despite a history of disciplinary problems, and Marsh said of the opener: "David has matured and developed into an important senior figure in the Australian team. He has come a long way. "We believe that he will respond well to the added responsibility of leadership." Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches that follow the final Ashes Test at the Oval, which starts on 20 August.
summary:
Steve Smith has been appointed as the new captain of the Australian Test team, replacing Michael Clarke. Smith, 26, already leads the one-day side and will also captain the Twenty20 team in the absence of the injured Aaron Finch. Fellow batsman David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain.

Clarke, 34, confirmed his decision to retire after his side surrendered the Ashes with a heavy defeat by England at Trent Bridge, which gave the hosts a 3-1 lead. Smith had already captained the side in three Tests against India last summer, when Clarke was recovering from hamstring surgery and back issues. The New South Welshman has played in 32 Tests for his country, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66.

"When Michael made his decision to retire last week it was a very straightforward decision for us to nominate Steve as his successor," added Marsh. "He has big shoes to fill but everything about him suggests he is the right man for the job."

Warner has earned the vice-captain's role despite a history of disciplinary problems, and Marsh said of the opener: "David has matured and developed into an important senior figure in the Australian team. He has come a long way.

"We believe that he will respond well to the added responsibility of leadership."

Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches that follow the final Ashes Test at the Oval, which starts on 20 August.

source: Smriti Mandhana ( born 18 July 1996 ) is an Indian cricketer who plays for the Indian women 's cricket team .
summary:
Smriti Mandhana is an Indian cricketer who plays for the Indian women's national cricket team. She is a left-handed opening batter and occasional right-arm off break bowler. She is the vice-captain of the Indian women's ODI team and the captain of the Indian women's T20I team. She is the first Indian woman to score a double century in One Day Internationals (ODIs). She is also the first Indian woman to score a century in both Test and ODI cricket. She was named the ICC Women's Cricketer of the Year in 2017.

Smriti Mandhana was born on 18 July 1996 in Mumbai, India. She started playing cricket at the age of eight. She made her international debut for India in 2013. She has played in 100 ODIs and 70 T20Is for India. She has scored 4,530 runs in ODIs and 2,290 runs in T20Is. She has scored 10 centuries in ODIs and 4 centuries in T20Is. She is the leading run-scorer for India in ODIs and T20Is.

Smriti Mandhana is a very talented cricketer. She is a very good batter and a very good fielder. She is also a very good leader. She is a very popular cricketer in India. She is an inspiration to many young girls in India.

source: Sophia Anna Bush ( born July 8 , 1982 ) is an American actress , director , spokesperson , and activist . She is known for her film roles in John Tucker Must Die ( 2006 ) , The Hitcher ( 2007 ) , and The Narrows ( 2008 ) .
summary:
Sophia Anna Bush is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist. She is known for her film roles in John Tucker Must Die (2006), The Hitcher (2007), and The Narrows (2008). She also starred in the television series One Tree Hill (2003–2012) and Chicago P.D. (2014–2017).

Bush was born in Pasadena, California, to Maureen (née Van Zandt), a teacher, and Charles William Bush, a real estate broker. She has two older brothers, Charles and Ian. Bush's father is of English, German, and Scottish descent, while her mother is of Dutch, Irish, and Italian descent.

Bush attended Westridge School, a private girls' school in Pasadena. She graduated in 2000. After high school, Bush attended the University of Southern California, where she studied theater. She left USC after two years to pursue a career in acting.

Bush began her acting career in guest roles on television shows such as The O.C. and Nip/Tuck. She had her first major role in the 2006 film John Tucker Must Die. She followed this with roles in the films The Hitcher (2007), The Narrows (2008), and The Hitcher II: I'm Back (2009).

In 2003, Bush was cast in the lead role of Brooke Davis on the television series One Tree Hill. She starred on the show for nine seasons, from 2003 to 2012. For her performance, Bush was nominated for a Teen Choice Award for Choice TV Actress: Drama in 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010, and 2011.

In 2014, Bush was cast in the lead role of Erin Lindsay on the television series Chicago P.D. She starred on the show for four seasons, from 2014 to 2017. For her performance, Bush was nominated for a Teen Choice Award for Choice TV Actress: Action in 2015 and 2016.

Bush is also a spokesperson for the organization Dress for Success, which provides professional attire to women who are entering the workforce. She is also an activist for gun control and women's rights.

In 2018, Bush directed her first short film, The Idea of Her. The film premiered at the 2018 Tribeca Film Festival.

Bush is currently working on her next project, a film called The Perfection. The film is set to be released in 2019.

source: Sophie Fearns said son Charlie, of Merseyside, needs to fly back to Seattle, America for experimental treatment unavailable in the UK. She said he urgently needs more T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital after the last transplant failed. His mother said she was "ecstatic" and "overwhelmed" by the "selfless amazing person" who paid for his treatment. Charlie has been ill since the age of three, she said. After a third relapse in April she said there was "no option" left for treatment for him in the UK. Mrs Fearns said the family, of Litherland, were left "heartbroken" when the first T-Cell transplant did not work. She said the news the treatment has been paid for was "completely overwhelming". "We don't know who this donor is but from the bottom of our hearts it means an incredible amount - not just from the foundation but everybody that supports Charlie." Charlie's father Rob Fearns said they were "extremely grateful" for the generosity of the anonymous donation. "He or she specifically asked to pay for Charlie. "We thought we were going to have to fight tooth and nail like last time to get the funds together." His parents said they received the confirmation via an email from the hospital on Wednesday saying someone had offered to foot the bill for them. Now Charlie has had financial clearance from the hospital, the treatment will start as soon as possible. Mr Fearns said he is expecting to find out the date next week. Information from Seattle Children's Hospital
summary:
Charlie Fearns, a 7-year-old boy from Merseyside, England, has been diagnosed with a rare form of cancer called B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). He has already undergone two rounds of chemotherapy and a bone marrow transplant, but the cancer has returned. Charlie's only hope for a cure is an experimental treatment called T-cell therapy, which is not available in the UK.

Charlie's parents, Sophie and Rob, have set up a fundraising page to raise the £500,000 needed to pay for the treatment in the US. They have been overwhelmed by the support they have received, and have already raised over £200,000.

On Wednesday, Charlie's parents received an email from Seattle Children's Hospital, where the treatment will be carried out, saying that an anonymous donor had offered to pay for Charlie's treatment. Charlie's parents are "ecstatic" and "overwhelmed" by the generosity of the donor, and say that it means "the world" to them.

Charlie is due to start treatment in the US next week. His parents say that they are "so grateful" to everyone who has supported Charlie, and that they are "keeping their fingers crossed" that the treatment will be successful.

T-cell therapy is a type of immunotherapy that uses the body's own immune system to fight cancer. It is a relatively new treatment, but it has shown promising results in clinical trials. In Charlie's case, the T-cells will be removed from his blood, genetically modified to recognize and attack the cancer cells, and then infused back into his body.

The treatment is not without risks, but Charlie's parents say that they are willing to take the risk in order to save their son's life. They say that they are "confident" that Charlie will make a full recovery, and that they are "so grateful" to the donor who has made this possible.

source: Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth `` Babyface '' Edmonds , Tracey Edmonds and Robert Teitel and released by Fox 2000 Pictures .
summary:
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel and released by Fox 2000 Pictures. The film is about the Joseph family, a close-knit African-American family living on the South Side of Chicago. The film follows the family over the course of several years as they deal with love, loss, and the challenges of everyday life. The film stars Vanessa Williams, Vivica A. Fox, Nia Long, Mekhi Phifer, and Michael Beach.

Soul Food was a critical and commercial success, grossing over $55 million at the box office. The film was praised for its realistic portrayal of African-American family life and its strong performances. Soul Food was nominated for two NAACP Image Awards, for Outstanding Motion Picture and Outstanding Actress in a Motion Picture for Williams.

The film is set in the South Side of Chicago and follows the Joseph family, a close-knit African-American family. The family is headed by matriarch Mama Joe (Irma P. Hall), who is the glue that holds the family together. Mama Joe's children are Maxine (Vanessa Williams), a successful lawyer; Teri (Vivica A. Fox), a stay-at-home mom; and Kenny (Michael Beach), a struggling musician. The family also includes Mama Joe's grandchildren, Maya (Nia Long), Ahmad (Mekhi Phifer), and Rashad (Brandon Hammond).

The film follows the Joseph family over the course of several years as they deal with love, loss, and the challenges of everyday life. Maxine is dealing with the aftermath of a divorce, Teri is struggling to raise her two children on her own, and Kenny is trying to make it as a musician. The family also faces the death of Mama Joe's husband, Big Joe (Alfre Woodard).

Despite the challenges they face, the Joseph family remains close and supportive of each other. They come together for Sunday dinners, where they share stories, laugh, and eat Mama Joe's famous soul food. Soul Food is a heartwarming and funny film about the importance of family. It is a must-see for anyone who loves African-American cinema.

source: Soyuz (rocket) . It was commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft as part of the Soviet human spaceflight program , first with 8 unmanned test flights , followed by the first 19 manned launches . Soyuz ( Сою́з [ sɐˈjʉs ] , `` Union '' , as in Сове́тский Сою́з , `` Sovetskiy Soyuz '' , `` Soviet Union '' ) is a series of spacecraft designed for the Soviet space programme by the Korolyov Design Bureau ( now RKK Energia ) in the 1960s that remains in service today . The Soyuz succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft and was originally built as part of the Soviet manned lunar programs .
summary:
The Soyuz is a spacecraft designed for the Soviet space program by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) in the 1960s. It is still in service today. The Soyuz succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft and was originally built as part of the Soviet manned lunar programs.

The Soyuz is a three-module spacecraft, consisting of a descent module, an orbital module, and a propulsion module. The descent module is the only module that returns to Earth. The orbital module is used for living and working in space. The propulsion module provides the spacecraft with thrust for maneuvering and deorbiting.

The Soyuz has been used to launch a variety of payloads, including satellites, space probes, and crews to the International Space Station. It is the only spacecraft that has been used to transport humans to the ISS.

The Soyuz has a long and successful history of spaceflight. It has been used to launch over 1,400 missions, including over 100 manned missions. The Soyuz is a reliable and versatile spacecraft that has played a major role in the development of human spaceflight.

The Soyuz is a three-stage rocket, with the first stage consisting of four boosters and a core stage. The second stage is a single rocket, and the third stage is a small rocket that is used to place the spacecraft into orbit.

The Soyuz has a launch mass of over 2.5 million kilograms and a payload capacity of over 7.5 tons to low Earth orbit. It has a maximum altitude of over 400 kilometers and a range of over 8,000 kilometers.

The Soyuz is a reliable and versatile rocket that has been used to launch a variety of payloads, including satellites, space probes, and crews to the International Space Station. It is the only rocket that has been used to transport humans to the ISS.

source: Space lasers are best known for blowing people - and planets - up in science fiction, and even the odd Bond movie. But one Scottish scientist is hoping they could, in fact, be the answer to heating our homes in the future. However, he hasn't ruled out the chance of someone could potentially use them for weapons. Space lasers: Dr Adrian Quarterman has suggested space lasers could be used to power homes in the future - but says the beams will be nowhere near as powerful as imagined in films like Star Wars (pictured) Dr Adrian Quarterman, of Dundee University, is working on a laser which will convert sun beams into energy, The Times reported. The satellites will orbit the earth, covered in mirrors to help it harvest the sunlight and convert it into laser light. The energy it then creates, using semi-conductors, can be shot back down to earth. If it works, it could mean solar power could even become viable in Scotland, or be able to restore power instantly to disaster hit areas. The physicist told The Times: 'What this will do is be able to fire at solar panels to boost the energy they are receiving.' Initial trials in Scotland were successful, but Dr Quarterman is now hoping to move the trials to Portugal. Similar?: Tokyo rresearchers have proposed a laser system to attach to the ISS which would be used to shoot down pieces of debris in Earth orbit (artist's illustration shown) Unlike the lasers in the movies, however, they will not be powerful enough to blind a pigeon, let alone blow up a planet. And it is quite different from ideas unveiled in a paper earlier this week, which could see the International Space Station fitted with lasers to clear up 'space junk'. The system, suggested by researchers at the Riken research institute in Tokyo, would use a telescope already mounted on the station to find and target pieces of debris up to 62 miles (100km) away. Powerful pulses from the laser would then push space junk into Earth’s atmosphere, where it would burn up. But this laser would also not be powerful enough to be turned into a weapon: the pieces it targets will be less than a centimetre in size. However, Dr Quarterman has acknowledged you 'might possibly have to worry a bit about who is in control' of his satellites.
summary:
Dr. Adrian Quarterman, a physicist at Dundee University, is working on a project to develop space lasers that could be used to power homes and businesses in the future. The lasers would be used to convert sunlight into energy, which could then be beamed down to Earth. This would provide a clean and sustainable source of energy that could be used to replace fossil fuels.

However, there are some concerns about the potential for space lasers to be used as weapons. Dr. Quarterman has acknowledged that "you might possibly have to worry a bit about who is in control" of his satellites. If these lasers were to fall into the wrong hands, they could be used to cause significant damage.

Overall, the development of space lasers is a promising technology with the potential to provide a clean and sustainable source of energy. However, it is important to be aware of the potential risks associated with this technology and to take steps to mitigate them.

Here are some additional details about the project:

* The lasers would be mounted on satellites in orbit around the Earth.
* The satellites would use mirrors to focus sunlight onto the lasers.
* The lasers would convert the sunlight into energy, which would then be beamed down to Earth.
* The energy could be used to power homes, businesses, and other infrastructure.
* The project is still in the early stages of development, but it has the potential to provide a clean and sustainable source of energy.

Here are some additional details about the potential risks associated with the project:

* The lasers could be used as weapons.
* The lasers could cause damage to satellites and other objects in orbit.
* The lasers could interfere with radio communications.
* The lasers could pose a hazard to human health.

It is important to weigh the potential benefits and risks of this project before moving forward.

source: Speech recognition ( SR ) is the inter-disciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics that develops methodologies and technologies that enables the recognition and translation of spoken language into text by computers . It incorporates knowledge and research in the linguistics , computer science , and electrical engineering fields .
summary:
Speech recognition is the process of converting spoken language into text. It is a subfield of computational linguistics that incorporates knowledge and research in the linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering fields.

Speech recognition is a challenging task because of the variability of human speech. Speech can be affected by factors such as the speaker's accent, the noise in the environment, and the speaker's emotional state.

Despite these challenges, speech recognition has become increasingly accurate in recent years. This is due to advances in machine learning and artificial intelligence.

Speech recognition is used in a variety of applications, including voice-activated assistants, dictation software, and closed captioning.

In the future, speech recognition is likely to become even more accurate and widespread. It is possible that one day, speech recognition will be used as a primary input method for computers.

source: Speech recognition ( SR ) is the inter-disciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics that develops methodologies and technologies that enables the recognition and translation of spoken language into text by computers . It incorporates knowledge and research in the linguistics , computer science , and electrical engineering fields . Speech recognition applications include voice user interfaces such as voice dialing ( e.g. `` Call home '' ) , call routing ( e.g. `` I would like to make a collect call '' ) , domotic appliance control , search ( e.g. find a podcast where particular words were spoken ) , simple data entry ( e.g. , entering a credit card number ) , preparation of structured documents ( e.g. a radiology report ) , speech-to-text processing ( e.g. , word processors or emails ) , and aircraft ( usually termed Direct Voice Input ) . The advances are evidenced not only by the surge of academic papers published in the field , but more importantly by the worldwide industry adoption of a variety of deep learning methods in designing and deploying speech recognition systems . These speech industry players include Google , Microsoft , IBM , Baidu , Apple , Amazon , Nuance , SoundHound , IflyTek , CDAC many of which have publicized the core technology in their speech recognition systems as being based on deep learning .
summary:
Speech recognition is the process of converting spoken language into text. It is an interdisciplinary field that draws on knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Speech recognition applications include voice user interfaces, search, simple data entry, preparation of structured documents, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft.

The field of speech recognition has advanced significantly in recent years, due in part to the widespread adoption of deep learning methods. Deep learning is a type of machine learning that uses artificial neural networks to learn from data. Neural networks are inspired by the human brain, and they can be used to recognize patterns in data.

Deep learning has been used to improve the accuracy of speech recognition systems. In particular, deep learning has been used to improve the ability of speech recognition systems to recognize speech in noisy environments.

Speech recognition is a valuable technology that has many applications. It can be used to improve the accessibility of computers and other devices for people with disabilities. It can also be used to improve the efficiency of communication.

Here are some additional details about speech recognition:

* Speech recognition is a two-step process: first, the speech signal is converted into a sequence of acoustic features; then, these features are used to recognize the words that were spoken.
* There are two main types of speech recognition systems: speaker-dependent systems and speaker-independent systems. Speaker-dependent systems are trained on the speech of a single individual, while speaker-independent systems are trained on the speech of a large number of people.
* Speech recognition systems can be used in a variety of applications, including voice dialing, voice search, and voice control of devices.
* Speech recognition is a challenging task, due to the variability of human speech. However, speech recognition technology has improved significantly in recent years, due in part to the development of deep learning techniques.

source: Star Trek: Discovery . It is the first series developed specifically for that service , and the first Star Trek series since Star Trek : Enterprise concluded in 2005 .
summary:
Star Trek: Discovery is an American science fiction television series created by Bryan Fuller and Alex Kurtzman. It is the first series developed specifically for the streaming service CBS All Access, and the first Star Trek series since Star Trek: Enterprise concluded in 2005. The series is set in the year 2256, ten years before the events of the original Star Trek series. It follows the adventures of the crew of the USS Discovery as they explore new worlds and civilizations. The series stars Sonequa Martin-Green as Michael Burnham, the first officer of the Discovery. Other cast members include Doug Jones, Anthony Rapp, Mary Wiseman, Shazad Latif, Jason Isaacs, and Michelle Yeoh.

Star Trek: Discovery premiered on September 24, 2017. The series has been met with critical acclaim, with praise for its writing, acting, and visuals. It has also been a commercial success, with CBS All Access reporting that it is the most-watched original series on the service. Star Trek: Discovery has been renewed for a third season, which is set to premiere in 2020.

source: Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event , originally broadcast via closed-circuit television and eventually broadcast via pay-per-view television , held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance ( NWA ) and later World Championship Wrestling ( WCW ) . From the 1960s to the 1980s , it was tradition for JCP to hold major professional wrestling events on Thanksgiving and Christmas , mostly at Greensboro Coliseum . Starrcade ( 1985 ) was the third annual Starrcade professional wrestling event produced by Jim Crockett Promotions ( JCP ) under the National Wrestling Alliance ( NWA ) banner . Starrcade ( 1987 ) was the fifth annual Starrcade professional wrestling event produced by Jim Crockett Promotions ( JCP ) under the National Wrestling Alliance ( NWA ) banner . Starrcade ( 1997 ) was the fifteenth annual Starrcade professional wrestling pay-per-view ( PPV ) event .
summary:
Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). It was originally broadcast via closed-circuit television and eventually broadcast via pay-per-view television. The event was held on Thanksgiving or Christmas Day, mostly at Greensboro Coliseum.

The first Starrcade was held in 1983 and was produced by Jim Crockett Promotions (JCP) under the NWA banner. The event was a success and led to the creation of the NWA World Heavyweight Championship. Starrcade continued to be held annually until 1990, when it was discontinued due to financial difficulties.

In 1992, WCW revived Starrcade and held the event at the Norfolk Scope in Norfolk, Virginia. The event was a success and led to the creation of the WCW World Heavyweight Championship. Starrcade continued to be held annually until 2000, when it was discontinued due to the sale of WCW to the World Wrestling Federation (WWF).

Starrcade was a major event in the history of professional wrestling. It was one of the first pay-per-view events and helped to popularize the concept of pay-per-view wrestling. Starrcade also helped to launch the careers of many of professional wrestling's biggest stars, including Ric Flair, Sting, and Hulk Hogan.

The event was a success, drawing over 20,000 fans and generating over $1 million in revenue.

Starrcade continued to be held annually throughout the 1980s and 1990s. The event became one of the most popular professional wrestling events of the year. In 1997, Starrcade was held at the Georgia Dome in Atlanta, Georgia. The main event was a ladder match between Sting and Bret Hart for the WCW World Heavyweight Championship. The main event was a triple threat match between Sting, Triple H, and Kevin Nash for the WCW World Heavyweight Championship. The event drew over 15,000 fans and generated over $3 million in revenue.

The main event was a triple threat match between Randy Orton, Bray Wyatt, and Finn Bálor for the WWE Championship. The event drew over 10,000 fans and generated over $2 million in revenue.

Starrcade has been held 35 times since its inception in 1983. source: Stephen Hammond said job roles would change when the paper system for car tax discs is scrapped in October. The minister allayed fears about job losses in a letter to Swansea East AM Mike Hedges. Mr Hedges said the minister's response would "give comfort" to DVLA employees. Concerns over the future of some of the 5,000 workers at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency centre were raised in October after Chancellor George Osborne's Autumn Statement. The chancellor announced that the tax disc would be replaced with an electronic system in October 2014. The new system will allow people to pay the charge by monthly direct debit. Mr Hedges had written to Mr Hammond asking for clarification of the government's intentions. In his response to Mr Hedges, Mr Hammond said: "It is likely that the introduction of a direct debit scheme may mean there will be a natural reduction in the amount of refunds received, in addition to the withdrawal of the tax disc. "This may mean changes to job roles and the need to train on new processes. "Any reductions in numbers of people needed for these activities will be managed through redeploying to other growth areas of the business." Mr Hedges welcomed the minister's assurances. He added: "Whilst disappointed that the changes will reduce the number of job opportunities at the DVLA, I can see the advantages of both paying by monthly direct debits and not having to show a tax disc. "I am pleased the minister is committed to redeployment rather than redundancies and I am sure this response will give comfort to many concerned DVLA employees."
summary:
The paper system for car tax discs will be scrapped in October 2014. This will mean that people will no longer need to display a tax disc on their windscreen. Instead, they will be able to pay their car tax by monthly direct debit.

The Minister for Transport, Stephen Hammond, has said that job roles will change when the paper system is scrapped. However, he has also said that any reductions in the number of people needed for these activities will be managed through redeployment rather than redundancies.

The Minister's response has been welcomed by Swansea East AM Mike Hedges. He said that it would "give comfort" to DVLA employees who were concerned about the future of their jobs.

The changes to the car tax system are part of the government's plans to make it easier for people to do business with the government. The government has said that the new system will be more efficient and will save money.

source: Stephen Hillenburg . Born in Lawton , Oklahoma and raised in Anaheim , California , Hillenburg became fascinated with the ocean as a child and also developed an interest in art .
summary: Stephen Hillenburg was born in Lawton, Oklahoma, on August 21, 1961. He grew up in Anaheim, California, and became fascinated with the ocean as a child. He also developed an interest in art. Hillenburg attended the California Institute of the Arts, where he studied marine biology and animation. After graduating, he worked as a marine science educator before becoming a full-time animator. In 1999, he created the animated television series SpongeBob SquarePants, which became a worldwide success. Hillenburg died of ALS on November 26, 2018.

source: Steve Bruce is adamant he can keep Hull City in the Barclays Premier League after a 2-0 defeat by Southampton left them battling to stay up. At the start of the campaign Bruce was targeting 10 wins to survive, but despite a strong start his Hull side have mustered just six and he is hoping 'nine or eight might be enough.' Hull were the better side against Southampton for the first 45 minutes but a James Ward-Prowse penalty and late strike from Graziano Pelle meant they left with nothing. Steve Bruce is confident he can keep Hull City in the Premier League this season and avoid relegation . They now have six games to save their season including nightmare fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham and Manchester United. But Bruce insisted: 'Everyone is up for the challenge and I'm sure and convinced that we'll do it. If we keep remaining positive I'm convinced we can take a couple of results which will take us over the line. 'We've had a wonderful three years near enough from getting promoted to getting to a cup final, staying up last year. I've always had something in my water that this season would be the most difficult because all of a sudden you've created an expectation and unfortunately we haven't been able to live up to that expectation. Hull were beaten 2-0 by Southampton on Saturday and are just two points clear of the drop zone . 'We've got our reasons for it, we've still got enough to keep us out of trouble I hope. We're bang in it but I'm still convinced we'll get out of it.' Bruce puts their struggles down to several long-term injuries to key players. At St Mary's Stadium, Mohamed Diame returned from five months out and James Chester from three. Michael Dawson and Nikica Jelavic have missed half the season and Robert Snodgrass has not been available at all. Bruce added: 'They are big players for us and unfortunately, at this moment, we haven't been able to cope. We've battled on manfully but not quite been good enough.' James Ward-Prowse slots home a penalty for Southampton against Hull as they moved up to fifth . Ronald Koeman's side moved to fifth in the table ahead of Tottenham, who lost to Aston Villa, and Liverpool, who play Newcastle on Monday. But the Dutchman left with his own problems, after he had to intervene when Sadio Mane tried to take the penalty when Ward-Prowse was first-choice. Koeman will speak to his squad to remind them that team rules cannot be broken by anyone. Koeman said: 'I already had a word with Mane but we will talk to the team about that because maybe I have to mention it a bit more clearly.'
summary:
Hull City manager Steve Bruce is confident that his team can avoid relegation from the Premier League this season, despite their current position of 18th in the table. Bruce believes that his team has the quality to stay up, and that they will need to be positive and take their chances in the remaining six games of the season.

Hull have been hit by a number of injuries this season, which has contributed to their struggles. However, Bruce is hopeful that some of his key players will be back soon, which will give them a boost in the run-in.

Southampton manager Ronald Koeman is also confident that his team can finish in the top four this season. Southampton are currently in fifth place, but they are only two points behind fourth-placed Tottenham Hotspur. Koeman believes that his team has the quality to finish in the top four, and that they will need to be consistent in the remaining games of the season.

Southampton were held to a 2-2 draw by Hull City on Saturday, but Koeman is not too concerned about the result. He believes that his team played well, and that they will take confidence from the performance into the remaining games of the season.

Koeman is also confident that his team can overcome the disappointment of losing Sadio Mane to Liverpool in the summer. Mane was Southampton's top scorer last season, but he has now joined Liverpool for a fee of £34 million. Koeman believes that his team has the quality to cope with Mane's departure, and that they will be able to find a replacement for him.

Koeman is also confident that his team can cope with the pressure of being in the top four race. Southampton have not finished in the top four since 2002-03, but Koeman believes that his team is ready to challenge for a place in the Champions League.

source: Stripes is a 1981 American buddy military comedy film directed by Ivan Reitman , starring Bill Murray , Harold Ramis , Warren Oates , P. J. Soles , Sean Young , and John Candy . Several actors including John Larroquette , John Diehl , Conrad Dunn and Judge Reinhold were featured in their first significant film roles . Joe Flaherty , Dave Thomas , Timothy Busfield and Bill Paxton also appeared early in their careers .
summary:
Stripes is a 1981 American buddy military comedy film directed by Ivan Reitman and starring Bill Murray, Harold Ramis, Warren Oates, P. J. Soles, Sean Young, and John Candy. The film follows John Winger (Murray), a lazy Milwaukee lounge singer who enlists in the U.S. Army to avoid being drafted. He is assigned to the 4077th Training Battalion, a ragtag unit led by the eccentric Captain Stillman (Oates). Winger quickly becomes friends with Russell Ziskey (Ramis), a fellow recruit who is also trying to avoid the draft. The two men must overcome their differences and work together to complete their training and become soldiers. Stripes was a critical and commercial success, grossing over $85 million at the box office. It is considered a classic of the military comedy genre.

The film's plot is as follows: John Winger is a lazy Milwaukee lounge singer who is facing the draft. He decides to enlist in the U.S. Army to avoid being drafted into the Vietnam War. He is assigned to the 4077th Training Battalion, a ragtag unit led by the eccentric Captain Stillman. Winger quickly becomes friends with Russell Ziskey, a fellow recruit who is also trying to avoid the draft. The two men must overcome their differences and work together to complete their training and become soldiers.

source: Stuart Campbell was arrested in the west of England on Friday following a complaint from a woman in south London. She had made allegations of harassment taking place over a two-year period. Mr Campbell, who was released on bail, said it concerned some tweets and insisted they were not threatening.  He accused the media of "innuendo" designed to encourage "speculations". The blogger, a former computer games reviewer who was born in Stirling but lives in Bath, has been a vocal campaigner for Scottish independence and launched the Wings Over Scotland blog in 2011. On Friday he tweeted that he would be posting less frequently than usual because of "reasons totally outwith my control (don't ask)". End of Twitter post  by @WingsScotland A spokesman for the Metropolitan Police said: "Police are investigating an allegation of online harassment. "The allegation was made after a woman, aged in her 30s, attended a south London police station. The harassment is said to have taken place over the past two years." Mr Campbell has been bailed, pending further inquiries, to a date in mid-September. In a statement on the Wings Over Scotland website, Mr Campbell responded to a report of his arrest which appeared in The Herald newspaper. He said that piece "has been written for maximum innuendo to allow the wildest speculations on social media - which are of course duly taking place - but the alleged events relate entirely to some tweets from our Twitter account, none of which have been deleted and all of which are still publicly visible. "Nothing more sinister or serious than some tweets has occurred or been alleged to have occurred. None of the tweets involved are in ANY way threatening, not even in a joking sense. That's all we'll be saying on the subject at this time."
summary: Stuart Campbell, a Scottish blogger and campaigner for Scottish independence, was arrested on Friday following a complaint from a woman in south London. The woman alleged that Campbell had harassed her online over a two-year period. Campbell was released on bail and has denied the allegations. He has accused the media of "innuendo" and "speculation". The Metropolitan Police are investigating the allegations.

source: Swansea University's Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott, are among a team who have found ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old. The discoveries were made in Acre state in the western Brazilian Amazon. Researchers from the universities of Exeter and Reading, and Brazil's SÃ£o Paulo, BelÃ©m are also part of the team. Their research investigated ditched enclosures which were concealed for centuries by bamboo-dominated rainforest until modern deforestation allowed the discovery of more than 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs". The team said the function of these mysterious sites is still little understood. They are unlikely to be villages, since archaeologists have recovered very few artefacts during excavation, and their layout does not suggest they were built for defensive reasons. Instead it is thought they were used only sporadically, perhaps as ritual gathering places, similar to the Maya pyramids of Central America, or Britain's own Stonehenge. Although Dr Loader - who has analysed soil samples from the geoglyphs - said the surroundings in which they were built were very different to other ritual sites around the world. He looked at phytoliths - a type of microscopic plant fossil made of silica - to reconstruct ancient vegetation; charcoal quantities, to assess the amount of ancient forest burning; and carbon stable isotopes, to indicate the type of vegetation growing there in the past. "The indications are that the geoglyphs were constructed amongst taller vegetation. So, unlike the towering Maya pyramids of Central America, they were likely not visible above the forest canopy, and this raises questions about their purpose," he explained. It had been assumed prior to the arrival of Europeans in the early 16th Century, the Amazonian forests had been pristine ecosystems, free from human influence. But the new research indicates a wide variety of plant species spread over 6,000 years, which could only have been artificially brought together by humans. It suggested instead of burning large tracts of forest - either for geoglyph construction or agricultural practices - people transformed their environment by concentrating on economically valuable trees such as palms. The team have likened it to a form of "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products. They said there is "tantalizing evidence" to suggest the biodiversity of some of Acre's remaining forests may retain a strong legacy of these ancient "agroforestry" practices to this day.
summary:
A team of archaeologists has discovered ancient earthworks in the western Brazilian Amazon. The earthworks, which are possibly 2,000 years old, are made up of ditched enclosures and are thought to have been used for ritual purposes. The team also found evidence that the Amazonian forests were not pristine ecosystems prior to the arrival of Europeans, but were instead transformed by humans into a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products.

The earthworks were discovered in Acre state, which is located in the western Amazon rainforest. The team, which was led by Dr. Neil Loader of Swansea University, investigated ditched enclosures that were concealed for centuries by bamboo-dominated rainforest. The enclosures are up to 100 meters long and 50 meters wide, and they are thought to have been built by people who lived in the area around 2,000 years ago.

The team said the function of these mysterious sites is still little understood. They are unlikely to be villages, since archaeologists have recovered very few artefacts during excavation, and their layout does not suggest they were built for defensive reasons. Instead it is thought they were used only sporadically, perhaps as ritual gathering places, similar to the Maya pyramids of Central America, or Britain's own Stonehenge.

Although Dr. Loader - who has analysed soil samples from the geoglyphs - said the surroundings in which they were built were very different to other ritual sites around the world. He looked at phytoliths - a type of microscopic plant fossil made of silica - to reconstruct ancient vegetation; charcoal quantities, to assess the amount of ancient forest burning; and carbon stable isotopes, to indicate the type of vegetation growing there in the past. "The indications are that the geoglyphs were constructed amongst taller vegetation. So, unlike the towering Maya pyramids of Central America, they were likely not visible above the forest canopy, and this raises questions about their purpose," he explained.

It had been assumed prior to the arrival of Europeans in the early 16th Century, the Amazonian forests had been pristine ecosystems, free from human influence. But the new research indicates a wide variety of plant species spread over 6,000 years, which could only have been artificially brought together by humans. It suggested instead of burning large tracts of forest - either for geoglyph construction or agricultural practices - people transformed their environment by concentrating on economically valuable trees such as palms. The team have likened it to a form of "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products. They said there is "tantalizing evidence" to suggest the biodiversity of some of Acre's remaining forests may retain a strong legacy of these ancient "agroforestry" practices to this day.

The findings of this study provide new insights into the history of human occupation of the Amazon rainforest and the ways in which people have interacted with the environment over time. They also suggest that the Amazon rainforest is not as pristine as it is often portrayed, and that it has been shaped by human activity for thousands of years.

source: Sylvia Blackburn, 72, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School, Kempston, last December. Brian Wright, 55, of Kempston, told Luton Crown Court he had been blinded by the setting sun. He accepted he had struck Mrs Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs Blackburn is now being treated in residential care. Judge Michael Kay QC paused the case for five minutes so Mr Wright could compose himself after he told the court how he had turned his victim's "world upside down". Mr Wright said: "I understand Sylvia was a much-loved lollipop lady, who was loved by the children. "I am truly sorry for what I have done to her and her family." Mr Wright's VW Golf failed to stop for a red light, the jury heard. The married mother-of-three, a lollipop lady for 20 years, had been on duty in Bedford Road as pupils left school. When the traffic lights turned red, Mrs Blackburn, who was wearing appropriate clothing, stepped out to escort a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road. Prosecutor Sally Mealing-McLeod said traffic in the other direction had stopped, but the defendant did not, and hit her. Mr Wright, of The Dell, said he could not remember if the traffic lights were red or green. "I was totally blinded by the sun," he said. "I just heard a bump. I was in total shock. "Since that day I have thought of nothing else other than Sylvia Blackburn and her family and the position I have put them in." The court heard the sun was 10 minutes from setting and could have been shining into Mr Wright's eyes. The trial continues.
summary:
Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, was seriously injured when she was hit by a car driven by Brian Wright. Wright, 55, told the court that he had been blinded by the setting sun and did not see Mrs Blackburn crossing the road. Mrs Blackburn is now being treated in residential care. Wright denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The trial continues.

The following are the core pieces of information described in the passage:

* Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, was seriously injured when she was hit by a car driven by Brian Wright.
* Wright, 55, told the court that he had been blinded by the setting sun and did not see Mrs Blackburn crossing the road.
* Mrs Blackburn is now being treated in residential care.
* Wright denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving.
* The trial continues.

source: T2 Trainspotting is a 2017 British comedy drama film , set in and around Edinburgh , Scotland .
summary:
T2 Trainspotting is a 2017 British comedy-drama film directed by Danny Boyle and written by John Hodge, based on the novel of the same name by Irvine Welsh. It is the sequel to the 1996 film Trainspotting, and stars Ewan McGregor, Ewen Bremner, Jonny Lee Miller, Robert Carlyle, Shirley Henderson, and Kelly Macdonald. The film follows the characters 20 years after the events of the first film, as they deal with the consequences of their past actions.

The film was released in the United Kingdom on January 27, 2017, and in the United States on March 17, 2017. It received positive reviews from critics, with praise for its performances, direction, and screenplay. The film was a box office success, grossing over $279 million worldwide against its $16 million budget.

T2 Trainspotting was nominated for two BAFTA Awards, for Best British Film and Best Adapted Screenplay. It was also nominated for two Golden Globe Awards, for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy and Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy for McGregor.

The film is set in and around Edinburgh, Scotland. The characters are all in their 40s now, and they are dealing with the consequences of their past actions. Renton (McGregor) is now a successful businessman, but he is still haunted by his past. Sick Boy (Bremner) is still a drug addict, and he is trying to make a living as a pimp. Spud (Miller) is still struggling with addiction, and he is trying to get his life back on track. Begbie (Carlyle) is still in prison, but he is about to be released.

The film follows the characters as they try to deal with their past and move on with their lives. It is a dark and funny film that explores the themes of addiction, redemption, and friendship.

source: Taran Hourie Killam ( born April 1 , 1982 ) is an American actor , comedian , and writer .
summary:
Taran Killam is an American actor, comedian, writer, and producer. He is best known for his work on Saturday Night Live, where he was a cast member from 2006 to 2016. He has also appeared in films such as The Hangover Part II, The Lego Movie, and Ted 2. Killam is married to actress Cobie Smulders.

Killam was born in Waterloo, Ontario, Canada, to Erin and Kevin Killam. He has two brothers, named Chris and Aaron. Killam attended St. David Catholic Secondary School in Waterloo. He then went on to study acting at the University of Victoria in British Columbia.

After graduating from university, Killam moved to New York City to pursue a career in comedy. He joined the Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre, where he performed in sketch comedy shows. In 2006, Killam was cast as a cast member on Saturday Night Live. He remained on the show for ten seasons, until 2016.

During his time on SNL, Killam impersonated a variety of celebrities, including Donald Trump, Mitt Romney, and Justin Bieber. He also co-wrote and starred in several SNL sketches, including "The Californians" and "The Digital Short."

In addition to his work on SNL, Killam has appeared in a number of films, including The Hangover Part II, The Lego Movie, and Ted 2. He has also starred in the television series The Mindy Project and Single Parents.

Killam is married to actress Cobie Smulders. They have two children together.

source: Telemundo ( [ teleˈmundo ] ) is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through the NBCUniversal division NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises .
summary:
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through the NBCUniversal division NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises. It is the second-largest Spanish-language broadcast television network in the United States, after Univision. Telemundo's programming includes news, sports, entertainment, and reality shows. The network is headquartered in Miami, Florida.

Telemundo was founded in 1954 as Spanish International Network (SIN). It was acquired by NBC in 2002 and renamed Telemundo. The network has since expanded its reach to include cable and satellite television, as well as digital platforms.

Telemundo is a major player in the Spanish-language media landscape in the United States. It is the most-watched Spanish-language network in the country, and its programming is available in over 100 million homes. Telemundo is also a major producer of Spanish-language content, and its shows are exported to over 100 countries around the world.

Telemundo is a significant part of the American media landscape. It is a major source of news and entertainment for Spanish-speaking Americans, and its programming is a reflection of the diversity of the Hispanic community in the United States.

source: Ten people, including four children, have been involved in a multi-vehicle crash in Brisbane's west. Three vehicles collided on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, on Wednesday afternoon. A 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries and a five-year-old boy with chest pain were the first patients flown out by rescue helicopter. They've been taken to the Princess Alexandra Hospital in Brisbane. Shortly after, a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl suffering from abdominal pain were also being flown out. The three car pileup happened at on the Brisbane Valley Highway, near Fernvale . Six others - including an infant and two young girls - have been taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for further assessment. A man has also suffered hand lacerations and two females escaped injuries. The affected stretch of the highway has been closed off, with diversions in place south of Fernvale. The Courier-Mail reports that earlier emergency crews found one person trapped inside their vehicle and Queensland Fire and Rescue crews used hydraulic cutting gear to free them. The Rescue 500 helicopter then landed at the scene and airlifted a number of patients to hospital. Police said the highway would be closed for a few hours with diversions in place south of Fernvale.
summary: Ten people, including four children, were involved in a multi-vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, on Wednesday afternoon. Three vehicles collided, and a 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries, a five-year-old boy with chest pain, a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries, and a six-year-old girl suffering from abdominal pain were flown to the Princess Alexandra Hospital in Brisbane. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for further assessment. A man also suffered hand lacerations and two females escaped injuries. The affected stretch of the highway was closed off, with diversions in place south of Fernvale.

source: Terry Crews . In football , Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the National Football League ( NFL ) for the Los Angeles Rams , San Diego Chargers and Washington Redskins , as well as in the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire .

He is known for his roles in the films White Chicks, Friday After Next, Idiocracy, The Expendables, and Blended. He has also starred in the television series Brooklyn Nine-Nine, Everybody Hates Chris, and Are We There Yet?. Crews was born in Flint, Michigan, and raised in Flint and Detroit.
